PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Discrimination against Women
To the Honourable The President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that ''The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State''. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 32 citizens), Boswell (from 39 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 22 citizens) and Robertson (from 402 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Fees: Overseas Students
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned students and staff of the University of Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. that in 1979 the Liberal Government introduced overseas student fees,
2. that those fees have been regularly increased since their introduction,
3. that the financial burden has caused hardship for overseas students studying here, who have limited earning capacity.
We call on this government to review the decision taken to introduce tertiary fees for overseas students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adelaide to Darwin Railway
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That in 1911, as part of its new responsibility for the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth accepted a binding legislative commitment to construct a railway from Adelaide to Darwin-a promise which has never been fulfilled.
The lack of essential transport links has had, and continues to have, serious consequences for the economic and social development of the Northern Territory, and indeed all of Australia.

That the future expansion of new industries in the Territory and new trade opportunities for Australia, particularly with South-East Asia and the Western Pacific, depend on the development of the railway to link the port of Darwin with the rest of Australia. The railway is therefore an essential national project related directly to Australia's overall prospects for future economic growth.
We therefore protest the Commonwealth's continuing failure to construct the railway.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Prime Minister and members of the Federal Government honour the promise made by the Commonwealth over 70 years ago , the promise made by the previous Commonwealth Government this year, and endorsed by the present Government in opposition to complete the construction of the railway by 1988, Australia's Bicentennial year. We call on the Prime Minister to give his personal assurance that the Commonwealth will honour its past and present promises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when debate on the National Health Amendment Bill was interrupted for the adjournment debate, I was debating the new pensioner pharmaceutical benefits declaration and the fact that the present Government promised, during the election campaign to abolish the declaration. SPEECH.PARA: It is a pity that the present Government cannot keep its word on anything as far as pensioners are concerned. SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention the view of the Opposition concerning the National Health Amendment Bill 1983, which deals with several different aspects of the national health scheme. It deals with changes in the arrangements for the payment of nursing home benefits and with the requirement for pharmaceutical benefit declarations. Also, it makes changes to the way in which certain domiciliary nursing care benefits may be revoked. The Opposition will not be opposing the general principles spelt out in the Bill. However, we will be proposing several tidying up amendments, which I will foreshadow a little later. I will also make some observations on the Government's position in continuing the pharmaceutical benefits declaration-a matter which has been referred to by Senator Walters- notwithstanding a specific undertaking given prior to the election that the declaration would be abolished and indeed a boast made in the second reading speech that it had been-it has not.

I will take those elements of the Bill seriatim. First, the legislative power regulating the establishment of, and standards in, nursing homes lies with the States. As a result, the system that has emerged has been one in which nursing home standards may differ between the States-and in fact do-and even within the States. While the Commonwealth has the responsibility of providing much of the finance used to support nursing homes, the differing State standards have meant that, at the Commonwealth end the administration of nursing home benefits has always been difficult. The difficulty has been compounded by a series of recent court decisions which have held that individual nursing homes have to be treated on an individual basis. The result is that what was administratively difficult has now become administratively impossible. It has become an administrative nightmare for any government. For that reason we will support, and would have introduced had we been in government, legislation spelling out the principles to be applied in determining the payments to be made to nursing homes and requiring that those principles be tabled in the Parliament and, of course, be subject to disallowance by either House of Parliament.

I wish to mention briefly the role which private nursing homes play in the care of the geriatric aged. As I stressed earlier, it is not possible to generalise about the whole of Australia because there are differing arrangements State by State but in Victoria, for example, there are approximately 14,000 geriatric beds. About half of these-7,700-are in privately owned nursing homes. Currently there is a waiting list for the admission to geriatric homes of 7,000 to 8,000 approved patients. The capital cost of constructing nursing homes in Victoria is about $20,000 a head, of which $5,000 to $6,000 represents the cost of land. The cost of providing a bed in a public hospital in the same State is between $40, 000 and $41,000. Thus, on current costs, it is about twice as expensive to provide a hospital bed as it is to provide a bed in a nursing home.

In the State of Victoria it costs about $60 a day to keep a person in a nursing home and about $120 a day to keep a person in hospital. What emerges is that it is certainly financially desirable, where medically and socially appropriate, to make maximum use of nursing home beds. If we can get a more flexible and more local provision of beds, it is socially desirable.

With that background, I turn to the specific amendments which I foreshadow now and will move at the Committee stage. These amendments are all to clause 3 of the Bill. Clause 3 (b), which amends sub-section (7) of section 40AA of the National Health Amendment Act, will empower the Minister to formulate principles which will be applied in determining nursing home fees. We will move an amendment requiring the Minister to consult with the industry prior to formulating those principles; that is all-just that the Minister should consult with the industry. We can see nothing unreasonable about that. It does not mean that he must take on board what the industry says. But in view of the place which this industry has, and in view of the advantages which can flow from co- operation between the industry and the government of the day, we think consultation is appropriate.

Proposed new sub-section (7B) in clause 3 of the Bill requires the Minister to have regard to certain matters when formulating the principles. We support that proposed section but we will seek to make amendments which will have the effect of requiring the Minister to consider in addition the need to provide for a reasonable return on the value of investment and the cost of delays which might occur in completing nursing home financial arrangements, particularly delays due to government inaction. I will spell these out in detail at the Committee stage. I understand that the clerks have distributed copies of our Committee stage amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—They will be coming round in a moment. We believe that these tidying-up amendments can be justified by reference made to comments by a judge of the Federal Court, Mr Justice Northrop, who sat on a number of court challenges to the way in which the Act was administered. In one of the cases His Honour held, in respect of an application of profit guidelines, that:

SPEECH.PARA: as a result (of the way the guidelines were applied) no person properly advised would consider purchasing an approved nursing home business.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it was all due to bad government.
—I am quoting a judge. I do not know why Senator Crowley finds this so objectionable. In that same case, at page 51, His Honour said:

SPEECH.PARA: One matter however does call for consideration. There has been unwarranted and inexcusable delay . . .
It is for those reasons that we will move that amendment at the Committee stage.

The pharmaceutical benefits declaration area of this Bill is an area of some difficulty. The origin of a need for some declaration was, of course, the introduction of a new concessional pharmaceutical benefit rate, the $2 prescription cost for certain people enjoying certain concessional rights. It was felt that a distinction had to be made between those entitled to the issue of medications at no cost, those entitled to the issue of medications at concessional cost and those required to pay the normal cost for their medications. To determine between these three groups of people, some kind of checking system had to be introduced because taxpayers' money was being used. The question was how to do it. Doctors could not be required to do it. I do not think they can be required constitutionally to do so, but perhaps the Minister will advise me on that. It was thought that the beneficiaries should be asked to demonstrate that they had an entitlement to pharmaceuticals either at no cost or at a concessional cost. The fact that the administrative arrangements made for this procedure first up were most unsatisfactory is now a matter of history. Pharmacists made it clear that they considered the arrangements inadequate. They were supported by the then Opposition, now the Government, and they made known their displeasure.

My successor as Minister for Health, Mr Carlton, agreed with the pharmacists that the administrative arrangements were clumsy and unnecessarily complex. He designed an interim form which was more simple than the first form. He indicated that he intended to simplify the form even further. He wrote a letter to the Pharmacy Guild of Australia before the election. In that letter, he summarised his commitment. To save the time of the Senate, as I do not want to read the letter written to the pharmacists by Mr Carlton, I seek leave to incorporate two paragraphs of it in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-

The government believes that anyone claiming a concession at the expense of the taxpayer should demonstrate their entitlement to that benefit in a manner that can be tested at law. It agrees that the mechanics of the patient declaration introduced on 1 January 1983 were unsatisfactory and has introduced a simplified interim declaration form that is currently being distributed. The Department of Health, under the Minister's close supervision, is examining options for reducing the pharmacist's workload. These include alternative systems submitted by the Guild, and the possible introduction of a plastic card 'Bankcard' type system (the most desired alternative) for implementation as soon as possible. The ultimate system will still require the beneficiary to substantiate the claim , something that did not occur under the previous system, but there is no reason why this cannot be accomplished in a simple manner. In addition the government will review all other paperwork in the pharmacy to try to reduce and/or simplify it. Any changes would be discussed in advance with the profession.

The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal would of course be free to consider claims from pharmacists for additional remuneration based on additional work, in accordance with the existing terms of reference of the Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. What did the then Opposition, the Australian Labor Party, say? Mr Hawke in his policy speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: One piece of wholly unnecessary red tape which we shall abolish immediately-
Those were his words:
on coming to government is the pharmaceutical declaration form which has been imposed by the Fraser Government on pharmacists, pensioners and the poor.
Dr Blewett wrote a letter to the Pharmacy Guild in which he said:

The pharmaceutical benefits declaration is an unnecessary bureaucratic imposition which will be scrapped by a Labor government. Any required details for identification purposes will be completed by doctors when they fill out the prescription form.
We know now that Mr Hawke and Dr Blewett gave commitments.

What has actually happened? I suppose that it depends on one's definition of what is a declaration. It seems quite clear to us that a declaration does remain . In the first paragraph of Dr Blewett's second reading speech, he claims to have met this commitment to abolish the form. He said:

This Bill will, among other things, honour an important election commitment to abolish the declaration that pensioners and concessional beneficiaries must sign when they receive pharmaceutical benefits.

He went on to say that it would be introduced by way of legislative change at the first opportunity. This is precisely what the Government has not done. It has abolished the old declaration form and replaced it with a new declaration form. Those who might have expected that the commitment was to do away with the declaration will be disappointed. The Minister's speech continued:
The new prescription form will simplify the present complex declaration form in four ways.
So there will be a declaration remaining in spite of commitments which have been made. I go back to Mr Hawke when he said:
One piece of wholly unnecessary red tape which we shall abolish immediately on coming to government is the pharmaceutical declaration form which has been imposed by the Fraser Government. . . .

In fact, Dr Blewett has reimposed the declaration. That is the point. We believe that is a breach of a specific undertaking during the election campaign. We have never had any doubt that a declaration form was necessary but we did not promise to abolish it; it was the Labor Party. It is another promise. It has been broken .

TALK.START.PARA: —Your system was unworkable.

SPEECH.PARA: We have copies of the present form. I am sure that they are known to honourable senators. There has been some doubt about the legal standing of one signature for the entitlement to and for the receipt of pharmaceuticals. That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'Whilst not opposing the Bill the Senate notes the failure of the Government to fulfil the Prime Minister's policy speech commitment to abolish the Pharmaceutical Benefits Declaration'.

Let me summarise. We believe that sections of this Bill are necessary and desirable and we support them. We wish to move some amendments in Committee to one of the clauses of the Bill. I will deal with those when the time comes. We note that a simpler pharmaceutical benefits declaration form exists but we also note in the process that the Labor Government has not honoured its promise to do away with the need for a pharmaceutical benefits declaration.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of time, it is not my intention to make a formal speech in this second reading debate. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its relatively rapid support of this legislation. The Government opposes the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume, which was also moved in another place, because it must be one of the greatest examples of hypocrisy that have ever been put down in this place. Let me give honourable senators a history of just what happened in this saga of the patients' declaration form. The patients' declaration form was introduced on 1 January 1983, as Senator Baume has said, when other concessional benefits were introduced for patients. The form was very complicated. It was so complicated that in a test performed by the Eden Monaro pensioners' association and the local branch of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia the average pensioner took about 15 minutes to fill it out and an average of three mistakes was made every time it was filled out. Pharmacies all over the country ended up with large queues while people were waiting to have their prescriptions filled out and to fill out the form properly.

SPEECH.PARA: There were endless complaints from pharmacists. People were not picking up their medicines from the pharmacies because the form actually frightened them. In other situations, agents would not pick up the prescriptions for their wives, husbands or other relatives because they were frightened of what would happen if they made a mistake on that form. The Pharmacy Guild complained bitterly. I know that in my State Senator Tate had consultations with the Pharmacy Guild, petitions were put around and an extraordinary number of people signed those petitions. There was general condemnation from the pharmaceutical industry, from the pensioners' association, from the medical profession, from-surprise, surprise-Mr Anthony, who actually looked at the form and realised what was going on, and, eventually from Mr Carlton, the then Minister for Health.

All the time there was that general condemnation, people stood up and defended that form day after day, over and again, accusing anyone at all who was against the form of being destructive and of frightening pensioners and beneficiaries generally. Their names were Senators Walters and Baume. They did it in this place over and again. Now they both have the gall to come in here, support an amendment such as the one that is before us and suggest that we as a government have not fulfilled our promise to abolish that pharmaceutical declaration form.

Under the old system a patient went to a doctor, the pension number was placed on the form and the patient or the patient's agent signed the form on receipt of the pharmaceutical benefits. Under the system introduced by the previous Government the patient had to fill out a complicated form to determine just what his or her entitlement was and sign that form on the front and the back. The pensioners could not understand it. Now only one signature will be required instead of two. The ridiculous amount of something like $65,000 was spent to send out two rubber stamps for doctors to use, on the back of their prescriptions. We have made the form simple. We have reverted to the previous system which requires only one form, yet Senator Baume and Senator Walters have the cheek to come in here and say that we did not abolish the old declaration form and did not fulfil our election promise. Disraeli was right: Conservative governments and conservative Oppositions are organised hypocrisy. There is not a better example of that maxim than the people sitting opposite us now.

The simple fact of the matter is that this new pharmaceutical declaration form has the approval of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, pharmacists generally, and the pensioners' association. It is not disapproved of by anybody, unlike the previous form. It is a satisfactory solution to what was a difficult problem. When we were in Opposition we used to hear Senator Walters, Senator Baume and others tell us that there is an enormous amount of fraud taking place in this area. They said that people were defrauding the system and that they needed to bring in this form to stop all these terrible people doing so. Over and over again we asked the then Minister for Health about the level of fraud. We even asked Senator Walters, thinking she might have some inside information as she was in constant consultation with the former Minister for Health and constantly went to the dinners of the Pharmacy Guild and was told by it, that everything was okay. We asked them over and over what the level of this fraud was. We conceded that if there is a huge amount of fraud taking place, something might need to be done. We could not get an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you told me in the Estimates Committee hearing.

—The only time an answer was given was when we came into government and I was willing to give Senator Walters an answer. The previous Government would not tell us. If we look at the record, we will see that there is not one occasion on which the Minister for Health or the Minister representing the Minister for Health in the former government would tell us. I told honourable senators what the figure was. The officials and the Department of Health agreed with me that the figure was perhaps $20m. That was a guesstimate. That was the best figure we could get. Frequently we were told in this place that there was an enormous amount of fraud, but nobody was willing to quantify it.
—I do not think that is right. I think we said there was potential for it.

—Over and over again we asked for a figure to be put on the level of fraud and we never got an answer. The simple fact of the matter is that this legislation will result in the abolition of the stupid, complicated, worrying and difficult patient declaration form introduced by the previous Government. As a result of this measure, patients will have to sign the prescription form once and identify themselves by their number once. Patients, patients' representatives and the pharmacy industry as a whole agree with this proposal. It abolishes that stupid, wasteful declaration form. The previous Government was being pressured so much by people who were being badgered by unnecessary bureaucratic processes that it would have had to do this sort of thing itself. We have fulfilled our election promise. To suggest that we have not is absolute nonsense. It may do the Opposition good to put these words on the end of the motion for the second reading of this legislation. It may warm the cockles of its heart, give it a warm inner glow or whatever, but the pensioners and beneficiaries who need the assistance of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme will now have a simple, easy, sensible system to deal with, something they did not have under the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The previous Government refused to change because it was stubborn and obsessed with the idea that out there hordes of disadvantaged people were trying to bring down the system. There is a considerable contrast between Senator Walters's vigorous defence in this place of a complicated pharmaceutical benefits form, which only achieves a slight cut in the estimated $20m over-expenditure, and her position on the tax recoupment Bills. She quite happily voted against, and spoke vigorously against, tax recoupment Bills which resulted in the taxpayers of this country being taken for $500m. I find it very hard to reconcile the morality of those two positions. Maybe Senator Walters can, but she has a unique mind in this area.

As for Senator Baume's comments on the rest of the legislation, he stated that he will move amendments in the Committee stage. Apparently, the amendments have only just occurred to the Opposition because it moved none in the other place. I am aware of the source of the amendments and I will talk about that during the Committee stage. The best thing we can do is to accept the fact that we have at last sorted out the mess in the pharmaceutical benefits area. We should talk about the nursing homes area in the Committee stage. I thank the Senate for its co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 2, clause 3, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 40AA(7), after ' The Minister may,' insert: 'after consultations with such representatives of proprietors of nursing homes as he considers appropriate,'.
(2) Page 2, clause 3, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 40AA (7B), paragraph (a), after 'operated', insert: 'in accordance with contemporary standards'.
(3) Page 2, clause 3, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 40AA (7B), paragraph (c), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
'(c) the need to provide for a reasonable return on the value of the investment in a nursing home;'.
(4) Page 2, clause 3, paragraph (b), proposed new sub-section 40AA (7B), after paragraph (c), add the following paragraphs:
'(d) additional costs incurred by proprietors of nursing homes because of the time taken to complete assessments, appeals and payments made by the Commonwealth; and
(e) any other matters which the Minister considers to be relevant and which are specified in principles formulated under sub-section (7).'
The first amendment is to page 2, clause 3. I want to add some words which I foreshadowed in the second reading debate. They are the words:
after consultations with such representatives of proprietors of nursing homes as he considers appropriate,

The amendment just requires the Minister for Health to consult the industry before he formulates the principles which are to apply in relation to the scales of fees required under proposed new sub-section (7A). Without such consultations there could well be continuation of policies which were severely criticised by Mr Justice Northrop in the judgment to which I referred previously; that is, the judgment in Nagrad Nominees Pty Ltd, V.G. No. 145 of 1981. In addition, it could just be a constructive co-operative approach. I believe that it could result in considerable improvements in the health scheme, in improved services to patients and in a diminution in government costs. I can see no reason why that should not be agreed to. It imposes an obligation only that there should be consultation with such representatives of proprietors of nursing homes as the Minister considers appropriate. I cannot see that that does any harm at all.

The second amendment suggests that at clause 3, paragraph (b) of the proposed new sub-section 40AA (7B), paragraph (a), after the word 'operated' we should insert the words 'in accordance with contemporary standards'. This amendment merely asks that the requirement that the Minister have regard to efficient and economic operation of homes be qualified slightly. We want to qualify it only by adding the words 'in accordance with contemporary standards'. We have in mind that without this qualification the clause could be interpreted as requiring homes to provide subsistence level services which might be quite out of touch with the justified expectations of the elderly to enjoy dignity. I am not suggesting that it would be interpreted that way but it could be. Adding the words 'in accordance with contemporary standards' would, in fact, simply provide a requirement for some protection for those who will be using the homes. They have expectations to enjoy dignity and a degree of treatment which reasonable people might regard as satisfactory. If there were full consultation and co- operation with the industry, really, such an amendment might be unnecessary. But until that is the situation we think it should be included. We think it might help those who are, in the end, the only people who matter and they are the people who use the homes.

The third amendment, which is another simple amendment, proposes that an additional consideration be included which requires the Minister to have regard to the need for the nursing home proprietor to receive a reasonable return on the value of the investment. I will not debate the matter in the Committee. But it is beyond question that the overall return on nursing homes is still fairly low. The inquiry by Price Waterhouse, the accountancy firm, stated that the average rate of return was 3 per cent. Virtually every court case in the litigious field surrounding nursing homes has resulted from the incapacity of individual nursing homes to receive an adequate return on investment and/or a recognition of costs which they say were necessarily incurred. There has been considerable argument between the Department of Health and the nursing home proprietors in this area. The refusal of the Department to recognise a reasonable return as a cost necessarily incurred has been highlighted in many of the judgments the courts have made.

The fourth amendment we are proposing asks that the Minister have regard to additional expenses incurred because of delays in completing assessments, appeals or matters of that kind, or delays in payments of Commonwealth subsidy. I mentioned earlier Mr Justice Northrop's comments about delays which have occurred in this area and his words that some of the delays were 'unwarranted and inexcusable'. If these delays occur, making the cash flow of a business more difficult is one way of making the survival of proprietors more difficult. Again , this is the kind of situation in which I think proper consultation with the industry could produce a solution which could be beneficial. I think it could be beneficial to the Department, to individual proprietors, to the patients and to the public interest. If delay is occasioned within government it really is proper that government should, in fact, bear the cost of that delay. This is proper if those delays are, as the judge said, 'unwarranted and inexcusable'.

Our fifth amendment asks simply that the other matters which the Minister considers to be relevant should be specified in the same way as the principles which are contained in another part of the Bill and that they should be subject to the Acts Interpretation Act. The amendments we have moved seek to achieve those various points. Before I conclude, I point out that I asked Senator Grimes a question earlier in the second reading debate. I mentioned that Mr Carlton had sought some advice as to whether one signature was appropriate and that he had gone to the Attorney-General's Department. I just want to get the answer which we think should be on the public record because we need the information. Is Senator Grimes able to help us with that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should say is that the acceptance of these amendments at this stage of the legislation-I point out that no such amendments were moved in another place and in a moment will suggest why they were not-will mean that the continuance of established policies and practices, and after all this legislation is about ensuring that established policies and practices will be continued, will not be possible pending the passage of the legislation after it has been returned to the House of Representatives for consideration in the Budget sittings. In the meantime, considerable increases in nursing home fees, which would have to be met by the sick and the frail aged, would occur. Ultimately that would lead to increased Government expenditure in this area. In the meantime, I point out to honourable senators, patients will have to pay.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot of what Senator Peter Baume had to say concerned consultation. Not only this Government but also other governments have consulted with the Australian Nursing Homes Association, the national body of nursing homes associations. Consultation with that organisation and with others occurs at meetings of the Nursing Homes Advisory Committee. I do not say this necessarily in a pejorative way but the problem is that there is another nursing homes association, the Private Geriatric Hospitals Association of Victoria, which broke away from the national body and will not have anything to do with it. Therefore it is very difficult for a national government to consult with that group. Obviously that association has no difficulty in consulting with the Opposition because every one of Senator Baume's amendments happens to come from that organisation.

I am not saying there is anything wrong with that but the amendments have been put forward by the Private Geriatric Hospitals Association of Victoria; they are not necessarily amendments agreed to by the national body.

The honourable senator is putting the case of one narrow section of the nursing homes industry. The reason these amendments were not moved in the House of Representatives is that they did not reach the House before the National Health Amendment Bill was passed. We ought to recognise the fact that Senator Baume is pushing the barrow of one small section of the nursing homes industry. There is nothing wrong with that, but that he is doing so should be recognised. As I have said, consultation is already provided for in the form of the Participating Nursing Homes Advisory Committee.

The purpose of this legislation is to ensure that established policies and practices of previous governments and Ministers can be followed in a way that would otherwise be inhibited by the result of court cases such as those to which Senator Peter Baume has referred. The practices are already established and accepted-except by a small group-and the Government wants to confirm that they should continue. Although there have been informal consultations on the matter, they have been with the national body, which knows what this legislation is all about. Senator Baume's proposed amendments include the use of the phrase 'in accordance with contemporary standards' but, as the honourable senator points out, there are varying standards in various States throughout the whole community. To include such phrases 'in accordance with contemporary standards' would be to insert a fairly ambiguous expression which would, I suggest, produce further problems of interpretation for the courts.

But Senator Baume goes even further and asks that provision be made for a reasonable return to be received by the nursing homes. The result of that is that public servants in the Department of Health will be asked to determine what is a reasonable return for a nursing home, something that I do not think the associations would welcome. Already the legislation provides that under the previously established policies and practices profitability can in fact be considered by the Minister when considering an appeal. Clause 4 of this Bill protects this provision so that, as I said, previously existing practices obtain and when someone appeals to the Minister the Minister himself can then consider profitability. I am sure that it is not really wise-I think Senator Baume on reflection would agree that it is not wise-that that should be a reasonable function for public servants to carry out. Profitability is, of course, important to the nursing homes. Senator Baume quoted a section from a judgment which suggested that under the present provisions no one would sensibly purchase a nursing home. My only comment on that is that people have been successfully purchasing nursing homes and making a mint out of them for many years. They were not doing too badly under the previous practices. Although the Victorian body and the national body do not like the existing practices and although they do not necessarily like the way that governments, of necessity, have to regulate in this area, I think the national body has been consulted and will be consulted in the future.

In general, the provisions are designed merely to continue established policies and practices pending the major revision of the nursing homes scheme in the Government's consideration of policy for care of the aged. The provisions offer protection to nursing home proprietors not under the previous Government's administration; that is, the principle of fee determination will be tabled in the Parliament and maybe disallowed by the Parliament. I think we have to recognise the fact that this provision arises out of a court decision which will create considerable difficulties but that the whole matter will be and in fact is under review while the Government is developing an aged care program of greater breadth and greater fairness.

To bring in amendments such as this at this stage and to hold up this legislation until the Budget session will not assist the Government, will certainly not assist patients in nursing homes and will certainly not be of much assistance in general to many of the nursing home proprietors. The amendments may be of assistance to some of them for whom profitability is of the outmost concern, but it will sow confusion in the industry and in the Government's administration of it if they go through.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a few comments also about the pharmaceutical form. There is no doubt at all that the Government has taken commendable action in replacing that disastrously confused form that was upsetting people to the extent that was documented and described earlier with a very much simpler form. It will use only one side of the form. It is a simpler form to read. It will require a single signature. Using the proposed form, pharmacists can revert to the previous easy practice of assisting people by filling in a number if the doctors do not put all that is required on the form. The most important point is that the form will achieve what it was set up for. The responsibility for the accuracy of an entitlement claim rests, as it always should, with the beneficiary. Whilst we have had some peculiar statements here about fraud and the amount of it and whether we were pursuing it, the Government appreciates that there is some potential for fraud in the pharmaceutical area. That is why the Government has unashamedly acknowledged that the declaration form should continue. The debate is not about whether that is the issue but about how to design a simple form that coherently gets the information that we want in the simplest way without disadvantaging the old, the handicapped, the non-English reading and so on.

The interesting thing is that this form was introduced by the Opposition as a mechanism to crack down on pharmacy fraud. The onus was going to be placed on the pharmacist to see that the declaration on the back of the form was filled in correctly. The form included a statement pointing out that false and misleading information would subject the patient or the agent, in this case possibly the pharmacist, to a $1,000 fine or six months gaol. Interestingly there was no clear indication of who would decide if it was the patient or the agent who would be fined or gaoled. It became clear that many patients thought it meant them and they were often so frightened by the threat that they did not even come back for their medicines. However, Mr Carlton, the then Minister for Health, persisted. Although he knew it would make it very difficult for everybody, including a lot more paperwork for pharmacists, he stated:
But we have large sums of money going out on things like pharmaceutical benefits and medical benefits.

He said that he would make sure that the money would go out honestly and in the right direction. What the form showed essentially was the insensitivity of the previous Government to people in the community. That is really what it was about . It paid no regard to the hardship, the confusion, the chaos or the fear that it created in thousands of Australian people and, in particular, the people who were timid, old or disadvantaged in the pursuit of an area of potential fraud. Even more remarkable was the fact that the fraud was assessed as being done by pharmacists yet it was the people needing medicines who were grossly upset by the Government's procedures.

The then Government's bullets were aimed at the wrong target. However, Mr Carlton persisted unrepentant and in the face of all sorts of evidence he would not change his mind at all on the forms. It is interesting to note, and I will not delay the Senate with all the quotes that I have to justify this stand, that on 6 December Mr Carlton said that he was spending $460m of taxpayers' money on pharmaceuticals but only one month earlier he was spending $300m worth of taxpayers' money on pharmaceuticals. Either there was an enormous increase in expenditure in December or he was not too accurate in his figures. If he could be out $160m in the space of a month it does make a piddling small amount of $ 20m potential fraud. I am not justifying the fraud, please understand that, but I am suggesting that if the former Minister could be $120m wrong from one month to another, I cannot imagine that both figures were right, perhaps he was not reliable in other areas.

Eventually he realised-it took him a long time to do so-that the forms were ' hideous' and a 'fiasco'. The Minister who introduced them actually overruled them. At last he sympathised with the outrage generated by their introduction. He said that he 'was astonished at the form's confusing design'. He admitted that 'the implementation of the declaration was badly handled' and he proposed to abolish the form and replace it with a plastic card issued to pensioners and unemployed people. Fortunately we had an election before he was able to do all of those things. We now have a government that has introduced a very simple form that achieves all that is necessary to check possible fraud but does nothing to disadvantage or confuse people. The Opposition has been at pains to insist that we are not honouring our promises. This form change is a clear example of how this Government is doing what it was elected to do-clear up the mess created by the previous Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government in its bringing forward of this proposal which will ensure that the only entitlement information required of somebody seeking a pharmaceutical benefit will be that on the front of the prescription form a single signature should appear which will allow the pharmacist to determine whether the patient should pay the $2 charge for health care card and pharmaceutical benefits concession card holders or receive the medication free as a pensioner health benefits card holder. SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this legislation reflects a great victory. It is a victory for pensioners and other disadvantaged people throughout the community. It is a victory for the small business section in our society because most chemists and pharmacists are, of course, small business people. It is a victory for those concerned citizens who deluged this chamber with signatures on petitions protesting about the intimidatory and confusing form, the back of which the then Government required should be filled in, double signed and all the rest. Senator Peter Baume is smiling but he will not smile in a moment. As I say, it is a victory for people who are most disadvantaged in our society-the people holding pensioner health benefit cards and entitled to get medication free.

By definition, normally we are talking about the frail and the elderly in our community-those perhaps with failing eyesight and those perhaps who do not have the ability in literacy which one would hope a decent education system would produce. One need only to refer to the report of the Review of Post-arrival Programs and Services to Migrants Committee-the Galbally committee-which showed that there are very high levels of functional illiteracy in the community. To be faced with a warning on the bottom of a form threatening a $1,000 fine or six months imprisonment for failure to fill in the form correctly was indeed an intimidatory experience for most elderly and frail people, particularly for those who are perhaps not as literate as they might be and particularly for recent arrivals in this country who do not have an adequate command of English. Of course, when I raised this matter back in November 1982, Senator Baume had this to say:
I have looked at the forms. I believe they would be ones that most people could fill in.
In respect of my point about those who perhaps do not have the capacity to understand English because they are recent arrivals in this country, he said:
If any explanation of the forms needs to be done that can be arranged through interpreter services in appropriate languages.

This is what he had to say about somebody who presents himself with a doctor's prescription at a pharmacy to acquire some much needed medication. Senator Peter Baume said: 'Oh, he can go to the interpreter service if he is having difficulty with the forms'. That is how compassionate and understanding he was at that time . The new much simplified form represents a great victory for these people.

It also represents a victory for small business in Australia because pharmacists and chemists are the ones whose business was most disrupted by the bureaucratic hassle which the previous Government forced upon them. If honourable senators had any contact with small business people operating city pharmacies, particularly pharmacies which require medicines to be sent by bus into country districts, they would know that this form created absolute chaos and confusion. It also distracted pharmacists from their primary task of safely and efficiently dispensing medicine to those who presented a prescription from their doctor. I was deluged in Tasmania with many requests from pharmacists who pointed out that intolerable strains were being put upon the conduct of their businesses, requiring hours of extra work each week for which, of course, they were not reimbursed and which, as I say, diverted them from their primary task of dispensing medicines-their professional duty within the community. However, the then Government was making them agents of the bureaucracy.

Thirdly, of course, the legislation represents a great victory for those people who, particularly in South Australia and, with Senator McIntosh's help, in Western Australia, signed thousands and thousands of petitions in order to indicate their support for action to get rid of the form which the then Government had imposed on the community. The fact is that within a couple of weeks and with the co-operation of 85 per cent of pharmacies in Tasmania I managed to get approximately 9,000 signatures on a petition condemning the Government's form. I know that Senator McIntosh achieved something of the same scale in Western Australia. The scale of that response over a short period of weeks earlier this year shows, I believe, that the Government was entirely out of touch with the people in this respect.

It is true that the Government has a right to protect the community against any defrauding of the revenue and that is why this simple form requires the signature of the person getting the benefit. I do not think that one can really say that that is not a sensible proposal. In fact, it was insisted upon by the Commonwealth law officers. In that respect one cannot argue with it. As I say, it is really a victory for ordinary common sense to prevail. It was largely the democratic processes of petitions to this Parliament, an ancient, democratic right which was utilised by people, particularly in Tasmania and Western Australia, which brought to the attention of government-the new Government in particular-the need for some alteration in this regard.
