TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter--

—I am sorry, but that is a matter that has been referred to in judgments given in court. I wish to ask the Minister a perfectly reasonable question: Will he undertake to have the Government keep that kind of issue before it? It may well be that an amendment like that may turn out to be appropriate. I think the Minister wants the legislation up and running and believes that acceptance of the Opposition's amendments would delay it. I think that is a perfectly proper observation on his part. The House of Representatives might have had to come back next week to deal with another matter but, because of a vote taken in this place yesterday, that is no longer the case. Will the Minister take on board the spirit, particularly of that proposed amendment and the other amendments dealing with consultation? I think their acceptance could lead to a better outcome in the whole area of nursing home provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two questions have arisen from the last two speeches made by honourable senators. I will deal firstly with the question asked by Senator Tate. Of course, the Government will keep an open mind on the effectiveness of the new pharmaceutical benefits form. We will consult the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, pharmacists generally, pensioner associations or anyone else who has a view on the matter, on the effectiveness of this form and any difficulty which may arise, with a view to modification should that be necessary. I thank Senator Peter Baume for recognising that this legislation should go through and for his statement that he will not unnecessarily delay the passage of this legislation by calling for divisions et cetera. I think it is important to remember, I said previously, that the legislation provides that the matter of costs due to delays et cetera can be brought up with the Minister. In the spirit of co-operation, I will take on board the honourable senator's suggestion and guarantee to speak to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) about the possibility of taking costs into account, particularly costs that are due to delays in the bureaucratic process and not the fault of the nursing homes.

SPEECH.PARA: On the matter of consultation generally, I think it is important to realise that this Government does consult, and the previous Government consulted, the nursing homes through the Nursing Homes Advisory Committee. The problem arises when groups have disagreements and break away. As the honourable senator will know, the problem is deciding what is a reasonable consultation. To some people it means consulting every nursing home proprietor in the country and to do that is just not possible. We have no desire to see continual conflict and war between the Government and the nursing home proprietors in this country. I feel sure that as we develop a new policy in a new regime for caring for the aged we will arrive at a more satisfactory situation. Of necessity, an arrival at such a satisfactory situation will mean that both sides believe that they have been properly consulted and that there has been broad consultation throughout the community with consumers, nursing home proprietors and other organisations that care for the aged. I thank the Opposition for its co-operation in this matter.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND REPATRIATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Senator Gietzelt:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill. Once again the present Government has broken promises. I do not think that anyone on the Government benches would deny that. It is not so much a case of the Government's breaking the promises it made to the pensioners but of making those promises in the beginning when it knew that eventually it would break them. That is the tragedy of the situation. That, I believe, is the whole crux of what the Opposition has called the dishonest approach of this Government. The promises made at election time were conceived in deceit and dishonesty. The Government is grossly culpable and we on this side of the chamber will continue to criticise it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are told that the Government will save $167m by this legislation. The Government is prepared to save $167m out of the pockets of those pensioners 70, 80 and 90 years of age. Where will it spend that money? I suppose it will go towards the $427m that we are told Medicare will cost in the first year. Two hundred thousand elderly people will be affected and the Government will take from those people the whole of the $51.45 or at least some of it.

The Opposition is concerned mainly about the retrospectivity of this legislation. It has said that the legislation will force those elderly people to take lower standards of accommodation. Some of them are sick, some of them are in nursing homes, others are looking after themselves in units. They have been told that when November comes they will have to move out of their accommodation into a lower standard of accommodation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the threshhold amount?
—That, we believe, is retrospectivity.
—What is the threshhold amount?
—She is not going to answer.

—Perhaps I should quote a few of the statements that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) made about this matter. I am quite sure that the honourable senators who are interjecting now would not be commenting if they remembered those statements clearly. On 17 March, in a Press release, Senator Grimes said:

SPEECH.PARA: Pensions are not under threat. No proposals have been made to change the present pension system, nor have there been any such discussions by the Government.
He said: 'No proposals have been made to change the present pension system'. On 6 April, in a Press release headed 'Speculation on pension cuts unfounded', he said:

Speculation on pension cuts in today's 'Age' is totally without foundation. It is not supported by the text of the Department of Finance Forward Estimates Report, prepared for the Economic Summit on which it is ostensibly based.
Such ill-founded speculation on the part of the 'Age' can only cause confusion and anxiety amongst many persioners and beneficiaries.
There is no sound from the Government benches now. At the National Economic Summit Conference he said:
There is . . . little scope to tighten existing income tests. Indeed, there are grounds for regarding . . . them as already too harsh.

Was it just a good idea at the time to say that sort of thing? He believed that already there were grounds for deciding that income tests might be too harsh. ' We have no intention at all of taking any money out of the pockets of pensioners ', he said. A report in the Bulletin of 10 May stated:

There can be no question of reducing the current level of pensions provided. ( The new Labor Government has promised to increase the level.) Apart from the fact that any government that tried to reduce the pension would, in the words of . . . Senator Don Grimes, 'be shot at dawn,'-

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you the main speaker for the Opposition? This is appalling.

—Senator Tate says that to quote these things is quite appalling , that it is quite appalling to remind Government senators opposite that it was their Minister for Social Security who made these promises to the people of Australia. Senator Tate says that to quote these now is appalling. He does not want us to be honest about it. He says: 'Do not look at what we have said-that is an appalling thing to do.' Senator Tate ought to be ashamed of himself. I hope that from now on he will keep quiet.
—Why do you hate true Tasmanians?

—The honourable senator is in so much trouble back home that he should keep very quiet about Tasmania. When the previous Government froze the pension for those on higher incomes at $51 for a single person and $88 for a married couple we did not do so retrospectively. We did not say: 'Okay, we will abolish that'. We said: 'We will freeze it at what you have, so your standard of living can be maintained. We will not take it away from you'. Let us look at what Senator Grimes said on that occasion. I hope that Senator Tate will not say that to do so is dishonest. As reported at page 1468 of Hansard for 19 October 1978, Senator Grimes, in referring to the freezing of the pension of those aged 70 years and over who receive higher incomes, said:

SPEECH.PARA: We find this proposal to reimpose any sort of income test sufficient reason to oppose this clause.
. . . the burden of this action should not fall on people within that age group . . .
As reported at page 1469, he added:
. . . I believe that it is wrong to reintroduce an income test of any kind on pensions received by people aged 70 years . . .

That is what Senator Grimes said when the previous Government introduced the Social Services Amendment Bill. He went on to suggest that the Government had a psychological desire to kick the less fortunate of the community in the teeth. He asked what the Government was doing to the over 70s and stated that it was kicking the pensioners below the belt and at the very least, causing great confusion to the elderly. But he did not stop there. He made some very good statements at that time-in a purely political fashion, considering the retrospective action his Government is taking today. The action we took then was not retrospective. He went on to say that the previous Government was passing mean legislation, making pensioners bear an excessive share of the Government's economic measures at little gain to the public purse. As I noted earlier, he said:
I believe . . . it is wrong to reintroduce an income test of any kind on pensions received by people aged 70 years and over . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said this?
—Senator Grimes had a lot to say at that time.
—Who, the Minister?

—The present Minister. Not satisfied with that, the Leader of the then Opposition, Bill Hayden, had a go. He supported Senator Grimes. I might pick up Senator Tate's earlier interjection. Bill Hayden said:

SPEECH.PARA: The argument about millionaires receiving pensions is a cruel and emotive device to cover up the Government's real intentions.

He said that our Minister for Health was using this argument to justify ripping the pension off ordinary people with modest savings that they had worked for all their lives. That is what the then Leader of the Labor Party said. Finally, let us look at what Senator Grimes said at the National Economic Summit Conference- that great event that was held to obtain consensus and to bring Australia together. The Government maintains that it wishes to bring Australia together, yet at this moment the Tasmanian Government is across the road at the High Court . What a ridiculous statement this Government made when it talked of bringing Australia together. It went to the people with a slogan of bringing Australia together, yet at the moment our State is before the High Court. At the Summit, Senator Grimes, on the subject of all social security means tests, said:

It could well be argued that in many areas we have already gone too far. The interaction of positive taxation and income tests can result in effective marginal tax rates for some 80 per cent, or more, . . .

He said that already in some areas the effective rate of tax was 80c in the dollar. I said that I would speak very briefly on this Bill. There is a lot more that I would like to say and to put to the people of Australia on how our Government brought in all the humane areas of the pensioner health scheme and pension benefits. The present Government is now committed to rip up those benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of honourable senators opposite, I remind the Senate that the means test for the pension for people over 75 was abolished by the then Labor Government in 1973 and for those over 70 in 1975, leaving one to suppose that, had that Labor Government continued, ultimately there would have been no means test on pensions and that they would indeed have been acknowledged as a right and not a privilege for people at the end of their working lives. In 1978 the income test was unfortunately re- introduced by the then Liberal Government, leaving the no-means-test pension for the over-70s frozen at the 1978 level of $51.45 per week instead of $81.60 for those satisfying the means test. It is in fact this 'frozen pension' that is being affected by the proposed legislation. The argument has been put in all sorts of areas by the present Government that now is the time for sacrifices to be made by everybody and the over-70s are not excluded from these sacrifices.

SPEECH.PARA: Emotional arguments have been brought up about people like Lang Hancock and Sir William McMahon. People have waved their arms in the air and said how appalling it is that people on the sorts of incomes received by those two people should continue to be entitled to the frozen pension. I suggest that such people represent a very small section of the community. It seems to me that there certainly would not be sufficient of them to manage to rack up the $167m which the Government anticipates saving in the eight months that this will operate. Most people over 70 years of age have already made sacrifices all their working lives and often since retirement. Those people have saved hard. Some of them have acquired superannuation payments. Some of them have sold their family home to move into a smaller unit, and then invested the capital. They tend to be the sorts of people who invest their money in fairly long term deposit schemes which are predominantly used for investment capital in this country. Therefore, it is their money which is being put to work to produce some of the jobs in which the present Government says it would like to see an increase.

The really wealthy people will not be affected. They have the cunning, the expertise and the legal and accounting advice to rearrange their affairs so that they remain immune. I would suggest that the Government has inadvertently indicated this in the line in the economic statement which shows what the savings will be over the next three financial years. While savings are to increase in the next financial year, they will drop in the subsequent year. I suggest that the Government is at least tacitly acknowledging either that all of these people are going to die of shock at the new scheme or that some of them are going to rearrange their business so that they avoid being caught by the means test. I acknowledge that the limits which are set in the legislation are fairly generous. However, that is not the point. I go back to the statement that I made at the beginning: Pensions should not be seen as a handout. They are an entitlement. They are an entitlement for which people have paid taxes all their lives. Of course, the more one earns the more tax one pays and, presumably one could then say, the greater one's entitlement is.

Most elderly people will end their lives in a nursing home of some sort or another. Nursing homes are not cheap places in which to stay, particularly if one remains there for 10 years or more. Many elderly people need or prefer to buy into a nursing home which is run by an organisation with which they have had an association all their lives. It is my belief that they deserve not only to be able to retain the capital they need to do this but also not to be further distressed, confused and upset over this sort of legislation. It is for that reason that I intend to offer my support to the Opposition's amendment to the second reading motion. I believe the legislation imposes a disadvantage on one of the most vulnerable sections of our community and that it fails to address the vital question of equity for all social security beneficiaries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Haines, the Opposition has not moved an amendment yet.
—Had it, I would have!
—Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to do that now, then Senator Haines will have-
—No, I will call you after Senator Haines has finished. You cannot interrupt Senator Haines's speech.

—I repeat: If the Opposition moves the amendment I will certainly support it. If it does not move the amendment, I support the sentiments which are endorsed in what was proposed. For the reasons that I have stated, I oppose this legislation. It is totally the opposite of something which the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, mentioned the other day, that is, the incorporation, introduction and establishment, if one likes, of a national portable contributory superannuation scheme. The legislation flies totally in the face of the concept that everybody is entitled to plan for his or her old age and to be secure in the final years of his or her life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to move the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Government.
—Do thank us because one of your lot knocked us back the other night.
—It was not me.
—Oh, no, not you! You would not!
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that it disadvantages one of the most vulnerable sections of our community and fails to address the vital question of equity for all social security beneficiaries'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just register for the record that I am opposed to this legislation. During the election campaign major pensioner groups circulated, I am sure to all honourable senators, a questionnaire asking them about their attitude to the means test for the over-70s pension. After careful consideration I responded that I was opposed to it. Having given that undertaking during the election campaign, I intend to honour it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reaction in the community to this change has been of two types and I think that is exemplified by the two sorts of speeches we have had here today. First of all we had a speech by Senator Walters who, when she was a supporter of the then Government, supported the previous changes to the over-70s pension and vigorously supported in this place the imposition of an income test and, prior to that, a means test on pensions generally. But when a change is proposed to the over-70s pension here today she comes into this place with emotive rather than rational arguments, and with a lot of noise to make, which does not add up to much. The second approach is that of Senator Haines, who is philosophically opposed to means tests on pensions anyhow and who has been utterly consistent in her approach to this legislation. I may disagree with her but at least her approach is consistent. She has said consistently that she opposes the imposition of a means test in these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that one must remember that on the morning after the economic statement was put out, Mr Bill Ottley representing the Australian Pensioners Federation made a very sane and very rational comment on AM pointing out that he understood the Government's difficulty, that something had to be done and that if it had to be done this was the way it should have been done. A letter from Mrs Fink, the executive director of the New South Wales Council on the Ageing, says in part:

I would like to take this opportunity to say that the staff of Council on the Ageing were relieved about your decision on the over 70 income test, . . . but the sensitive manner with which it has been handled is most satisfactory.

I think of all the decisions that were announced in the economic statement it is worth while remembering that this one has caused very little of the emotional response that Senator Walters talks about. As Mrs Fink pointed out, the Council was inundated with telephone calls from elderly people, but they were reacting to the situation emotionally rather than rationally. I believe it is up to members of the Opposition in this place and senators generally to act rationally rather than emotionally.

The simple fact of the matter is that before the election, prior to the freezing of the over-70s pension at $51.45, we had a firm and hard promise from the then Prime Minister in two places-one in Rockhampton and the other in Launceston-that nothing would be done to the pensions of those aged over 70 years. The first thing that happened in the next Budget was that that pension was frozen. It was frozen not only for single pensioners earning more than $200 a week and married pensioners earning more than $330 a week but also for pensioners in both cases earning considerably less than that. I have not had time to calculate those incomes but they were in the region of $120 and $200 respectively. That change was very much more significant than the change that has been introduced now. What is more, since that time the pension has stayed at that level and has been eroded by inflation until now it is 60 per cent of what it would have been when the change was introduced.

There is a very great difference between what was then done and what is now being done. In fact, before the last election, as Senator Macklin said, some pensioner organisations-not all-circulated a questionnaire. A question on that questionnaire was: 'Will you re-introduce the means test pension for those over 70?'. In other words, they asked whether we would abolish the means test which exists on increases now. When I answered that question I said no. I said that the economic conditions even then, quite clearly, would not allow that to be introduced. Of course, we changed. Prior to the 1980 election we believed it was a reasonable thing to reintroduce a non-means tested pension for those over 70 because of the way it had been removed. But we realised before this election that it would not be possible to do so. That is why it was not part of our election promises.

When the expenditure review committee looked at the areas in which we could cut down expenditure, it was concerned to make sure that such a cutback did not fall too harshly on those who could least afford it. Therefore, as honourable senators know, we introduced a means test, the lower limit of which is $200 a week for those who are single and $300 a week for those who are married. This group is still treated very much better than pensioners between 65 and 70. They are not unreasonable cutoff levels. I do not think that anyone in the community considers that these levels are unreasonable. They recognise that those over 70 may have the need for a greater pension income than those below 70. But I do not think that anyone is seriously arguing that a single pensioner earning over $200 a week in addition to the pension and a married pensioner earning over $300 extra cannot stand this sort of change in view of the difficult economic circumstances with which we are faced. I point out again to Senator Walters and her colleagues that we are faced with a budgetary situation in which the-

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again.

—I am not saying any more than this, Senator. The $160m to be saved in this area is important. Yet Senator Walters came into this place yesterday and quite cheerfully wiped off the Budget of this country some $500m to protect people who could patently afford to pay much more than the group about which we are now talking. The Opposition quite happily wiped $500m off the Budget of this country and protected people who had evaded taxes in this community and had forced low income earners and others to pay more taxes in previous years. Yet Senator Walters comes in the next day and cries tears of blood over this measure. I point out that the New South Wales Council of the Ageing, the Combined Pensioners Association and others, although they do not like this decision, have not carried on with the emotive nonsense that Senator Walters carried on with today.
—She gave you a decent serve.

—I can cop serves from Senator Walters any time because they are irrational. She is a master-or a mistress, perhaps-at quoting out of context. Above all, she is utterly irresponsible in the way in which she attempts to stir up emotions in the community. Quite frankly, in this situation neither she nor the few other people in the community who have tried to stir up emotions have had any effect at all. I ask honourable senators to look at the reactions of those who have a closer contact with the pensioner community than Senator Walters has.
—Have a look at Bruce.
—Heavens, the way Senator Walters is carrying on, we should have had a 15 per cent swing against us in Bruce. I did not notice that that was so.
—It was 6 per cent.

—Even Senator Walters's mathematics are no good. In fact, they are way out. The simple fact of the matter is, as I have said, that two approaches are being taken to this legislation. One is that of Senator Haines who is philosophically opposed to the means test in any case. Therefore, she is arguing utterly consistently when she says that she and those of her party who oppose the measure do so for that reason. The other is that of Senator Walters, who at other times has vigorously argued in favour of a means test. She has talked about hounding single parents to collect maintenance payments and about the unemployed who are allegedly ripping off the community. I remember in one case she talked about the fact that people in her profession who become unemployed should not need unemployment benefits because while they are employed they earn plenty of money and they should save for that eventuality. She has carried on in this rigid and strict way about the treatment of the disadvantaged in the community.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are talking, in the case of single people, about people who are earning $200 in extra income or, in the case of married people, over $300 extra income, on top of their pensions; yet she weeps tears of blood and heaps abuse on people on this side of the House. We are used to that inconsistent approach. We are used to that strange morality. We believe that this measure must be taken . We believe, in the total budgetary situation, which will become obvious in August, it will be seen, as it is seen by most people in the community, as a reasonable measure to try to repair the damage that has been done to this country by people such as Senator Walters and those who ran the country during the last seven years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I claim to have been misrepresented. I will be brief. I have never said that the unemployed were ripping off people. I have never said that single mothers were ripping off people. I have never made any of those claims. Senator Grimes did not quote me, but he said that I had made such claims in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walters's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two fairly important points which I do not think have yet arisen in debate on the Social Security and Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill, and two questions that I should like to put to the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) in the interests of people who are affected by this legislation. First, in support of Senator Haines and Senator Macklin, I should like to say that what they have said is in accord with Australian Democrat policy, which is the policy of any enlightened political party in the world now; that is, that these sorts of pensions should not be means tested.

SPEECH.PARA: We see a certain need on the part of the Government. We see that it has taken this money because it thinks that it can spend it in a better way. I am not canvassing that issue, but it has implications for my questions to the Minister, and they are these: What are the Government's intentions for the future in this regard? Does it see this legislation as a permanent thing, or is it prepared to reconsider it in the reasonably near future? I hope that the Minister will give some reassurance today to the many thousands of people who are concerned about that point. The second point on which I think the Minister should give a reassurance is this: The limits now placed-I think they are $200 for a single person and $333 for a married couple-seem reasonably generous in terms of today' s economy, although Senator Haines made some points on that. I think that the elderly people of this country are entitled to know one very decisive thing from the Minister, and that is whether these limits will be indexed; in other words, will the Government allow those limits to rise so that they are not eroded over the next few years by continuing inflation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason's questions are reasonable questions and deserve answers. In the first case, this change was made in the light of the Expenditure Review Committee's decisions looking at not only increasing expenditure to increase employment in areas such as housing and community works, but also areas in which expenditure could reasonably be saved. That is why this was done with those limits, which I consider are fairly reasonable limits.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, we are not satisfied with the retirement incomes policy in this country. In fact, two departmental committees or task forces are working on different aspects of this matter. We also have a policy-in the long term, of course-of introducing a national superannuation scheme. I do not believe, as Senator Haines suggested, that this sort of proposal flies in the face of a national superannuation scheme. Any national superannuation scheme in this country or any other country in which it now exists will have limits on it, particularly if it is a pay-as-you-go scheme, which it obviously would have to be. I do not think the introduction of a test such as this on extra income limits of $200 for a single person and over $300 for a married couple would militate against the introduction of a national superannuation scheme. Certainly , in the light of developing a more rational retirement incomes policy in this legislation and the other pension programs are being reviewed and will be considered in the budgetary context of not only this Budget but also budgets to come.

The indexation of these limits is not written into this legislation, as Senator Mason knows. Certainly, the cut-off points must be considered in the light of inflation in the budgetary situation, just as the myriad of levels should be considered. I remind the honourable senator that cut-off points in other pension means tests are not indexed at the moment. It is my general view that if we are to have cut-off points such as this in means tests, in fact, they should be indexed. That is not always possible in the budgetary situation but it certainly will come under consideration in the next Budget.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a third time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I draw her attention to an article which appeared on page 7 of the Australian newpaper this morning and which is headed ' Battle of sexes erupts on field'. In part the article states:

QUESTION.PARA: Women in the Australian Army Reserve who have been training and working beside men on field exercises for years have been told they can no longer serve in combat units.
The army has told them to transfer to units where they can find 'womanly' employment as nurses, clerks, drivers or cooks.
The move, which will affect several hundred women, brings the reserves into line with the regular army which does not allow women in its armoured, infantry, field artillery or field engineer units.
Apparently, this has come about as a result of, as the article states:
. . . a Federal Government decision on Thursday to make the armed forces exempt from the new sex discrimination bill . . .

I point out to the Senate that that Bill has not been passed yet by this chamber . I ask the Minister: Who authorised this decision? Was the Government consulted in any way in the making of the decision? Will the Minister, either acting in her own right or in offering advice to the Minister for Defence, attempt to reverse the decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article to which Senator Haines's question refers and make clear that I share the alarm and concern expressed by her. I sought immediately to contact the Minister for Defence to find out who authorised such a decision, if indeed such a decision had been made. Because the article was brought to my attention only an hour or so ago, I am not in a position to answer the question. First, I do not know whether the story is true, in that there has been a change of policy concerning women serving in the reserve forces. Secondly , if there has been such a change of policy, I cannot say why or on whose authorisation that has happened. I do say that the Government would be very concerned and would take very seriously any attempt within the armed forces or anywhere else to restrict the availability of employment to women. It is the intention of the Government, introducing the sex discrimination legislation, to broaden the opportunities for employment and training for women, including those in the defence forces. I can assure Senator Haines that I will be pursuing this matter. I hope to be able to answer, or have the Minister for Defence answer, the matters raised in the article in the Australian this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: I should clarify too that the defence forces will not be exempt from the provisions of the sex dis- crimination legislation. However, the Government has decided that certain duties that are classified as combat and combat-related will be so exempt. The list of duties to be exempted has not yet been determined . When it is determined, it will be determined by the government and will be implemented by regulation. It will be available to the Senate for perusal. It is my view and that of the Government that the list should be as small as posible and should be authentic, not one which seeks to exclude women from training and employment that in no realistic way would lead to combat. I share Senator Haines 's concern and I give her my undertaking that I will get further information concerning the article as soon as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister seen page 1 of the 1981-82 report of the Commonwealth Employment Service, which states that since the abolition of the Professional Employment Offices, the CES is providing less than satisfactory service for the professional executive job seeker? I also refer the Minister to the comment that the abolition of the PEOs has had adverse effects on the general operations of the CES because-

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there has been a reduced flow of non-professional vacancies from employers who formerly used the PEOs and an unavoidable loss of contact at the senior employer level.
I ask: What action does the Minister intend to take to rectify this problem? Will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, re-establish the Professional Employment Offices within the CES?

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Foreman has a long-standing interest in this matter. He has previously asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, questions on the same topic. I am advised by the Minister that he recognises the service to which the honourable senator refers has been unsatisfactory in the past, but takes the view that a return to the previous arrangements, under which these unemployed people were assisted almost exclusively by a single Professional Employment Office in each capital city, would not be the most effective way to meet their needs. Because of that consideration, on the recommendation of the National Director of the CES the Minister has decided that the CES should examine the extensive range of issues involved and develop a more up-to-date service for these clients. I am advised that this examination is currently under way and that the recommendations are to be placed before the National Advisory Committee on the CES, which is chaired by Mr George Polites of the Confederation of Australian Industry. I think that perhaps by the Budget session there will be a definitive response to the honourable senator's question. The matter is being examined. We hope for a report by that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney- General to the amendments to the Freedom of Information Act which he introduced into the Senate yesterday and which retain the provisions for conclusive certificates in relation to the documents set out in the existing Act. I ask the Attorney whether he recalls saying in the Senate on 29 May 1981 in the course of the debate on the Freedom of Information Bill:

QUESTION.PARA: So long as ministerial discretion in any form is retained absolutely and conclusively to deny access to these documents without being subject to second guessing or review by anyone else, it is our view . . . that freedom of information legislation is simply not worth having unless we can ensure that documents of this kind come within its ambit, too.
How does the Attorney-General explain the fact that his ministerial colleagues have formed the same view about the need for conclusive certificates as did the members of the Fraser Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, I recall using the words of which I am reminded by Senator Durack. It is the case that I took the view that it was desirable to remove the degree of ministerial discretion that is presently vested under the Act in Ministers in relation to security sensitive documents, internal working documents and others that can attract this exemption. The Bill introduced yesterday does not entirely remove the conclusive certificates provision but it is not true to say that there is no review process in relation to the exercise by a Minister or his delegate of the conclusive certificate power. In fact, it is proposed that there be a significant form of review through the Administrative Appeals Tribunal-not the highly circumlocutory procedure under the Document Review Tribunal of the previous legislation-with a power of recommendation in the AAT to the Minister, which ultimately, it is true, the Minister may reject, with an obligation nonetheless to make an explicit statement to Parliament as to the reasons why he is in fact rejecting that recommendation. This is a significant sanction which, as I recall, is not available under the present legislation. There may be a gap, as I said in answer to a question the other day, between total aspiration and total achievement in this area. Nonetheless I believe very strongly that the freedom of information legislation, as it will exist after the passage of this amending Bill, will be a very much more substantial contribution to open government in this country than anything that was able to be managed under the previous Government.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that the review procedure of the conclusive certificates which the Attorney has said is contained in his Bill is virtually the same procedure as that which the existing Act provides for review by the Document Review Tribunal? Is it not simply a fact that there is a change only in the body that will do it, namely, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal instead of the Document Review Tribunal?

—Even were the question in order, which, as Senator Tate reminds me, it is not to the extent that it is seeking to canvass the contents of a Bill before this chamber, the answer would be that, although there are substantial similiarities between the proposed new machinery and the existing proposal, there are significant improvements.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he intends to make any changes in the appeals system for people who have appeared before Social Security Appeals Tribunals and now believe they are not getting fair treatment from the Department of Social Security? Does he intend to retain the right of his Department to change recommendations from the Social Security Appeals Tribunals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Jones has implied, the whole area of appeals in respect of the Department of Social Security concerns me. It was clear to us in Opposition that there were some difficulties in the appeals system in that over half the people who appealed had their appeals upheld because the original decisions of the Department were admitted to be wrong. At the time a blitz was conducted on invalid pensions and the number of appeals rose to an even higher level. The first priority is to have a look at the early stages of decision- making to make sure that those decisions are, first of all, made correctly and, secondly, reviewed where necessary so that we do not have this situation of so many people appealing and appealing successfully. There are other aspects to the whole appeals system as it affects social security systems that need looking at. The first is the relatively informal nature of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and how effectively those tribnals are operating and the more legalistic nature of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the results that some of the decisions of that Tribunal are having on the social security system in general.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the discretion of the Director-General, I think it should be noted that that discretion sometimes works in favour of the claimant against an unfavourable determination; it is not always one way. But these and other aspects of the operation of the appeals system in general will be closely looked at by the Government and by me so that we can end up with a system, I think, which is not only fair but is seen to be fair both by the claimants and by those people in the community who are paying for the system. If we can get a fairer system and a system that is more satisfactory to everyone, I think we will get a more efficient system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry aware of the plight of the Queensland sugar industry which has experienced a period of downturn in world prices, drought and storm and wind damage? Is the Minister also aware of the assistance that this Queensland Government has given to the Queensland sugar industry in the form of rural reconstruction, loans from the Agricultural Bank as well as a $10m low interest loan to the co-operative mills and, two days ago, a further $10m aid to the industry? When will this Government respond to the repeated requests made by the industry and the Queensland Government for Federal Government assistance? When will this Government pull its Federal weight and honour its commitment made by its leader, Mr Hawke, on 20 February that he would give sympathetic consideration to the sugar industry for an industry loan or an underwriting scheme to include the 1982 crop?

—Yes, I am aware that the sugar industry in Queensland is in difficulty. I read the papers. I am afraid that I am not aware of the details of assistance given by Federal and State governments to the sugar industry, although I am aware that has been considerable over the years and the subject of much controversy. My colleague the Minister for Primary Industry is in Queensland today. I understand that this will be one of the subjects that he will be discussing. I will refer the details of the question to the Minister so I can get an answer as promptly as possible for the honourable senator.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Is it the policy of the Government to provide cheaper fares for air travel? If so, how does this policy square with the Government's decision to deny East-West Airlines Ltd access to Melbourne and Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government is committed to a policy of cheaper air fares, but it is committed in the light of the capacity of the industry to provide those fares. To that extent, the Government is tied to longstanding practices and policies by the Parliament over many, many years. I refer specifically to the two-airline agreement policies which had their origins in the policies pursued by the previous Government. In respect of the controversy raging at the moment about the decision of the Minister for Aviation, Mr Beazley , whom I represent in this place, to deny certain facilities to East-West Airlines, it has to be understood that the Commonwealth is obliged to uphold the law in this respect and that East-West, in fact, is breaching the legislation. Therefore, that does not put the Government in a position where it can easily ignore what East-West is doing.

ANSWER.PARA: The Independent Air Fares Committee was established by the Fraser Government. It has been delegated authority by the Parliament to establish air fares. Therefore I think the obligation rests with East-West to provide the basic information sought by that Committee's requests so that a proper decision can be reached in respect of the East-West decision to offer cheaper air fares from Sydney to Melbourne, even if the flights go via Albury. This Government, as distinct from the previous Government, is committed to a review of the two- airline policy which we have inherited as a result of the policies which were pursued by the Liberal-National parties. I find it somewhat difficult to appreciate the concern of Opposition senators, and particularly that of the spokesman for the Liberal Party, Mr Spender, who is in some sort of ideological mish mash at the moment. He does not know his way out of the problem that faces his Party which, after all, believes in a policy of rationalisation. Members of the Liberal Party have to make up their minds whether that is their approach to airline questions in this country or whether they will rely entirely on a free market situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister was asked a comparatively simple and straightforward question in short terms about the policies of his Government with respect to a particular decision which is pertinent now. The answer is clearly debating the question.

—The Minister, of course, is entitled to answer the question in a way in which he sees fit. However, I draw his attention to Standing Order 100 which states that a Minister, in answering a question, should not debate the issue.

—The Government is concerned about the price of air fares. It is attempting to rationalise its policy. That is why it has called for a review of the two airlines agreement. In light of that situation we cannot stand by and see an independent airline taking action which is in breach of existing legislation. One would expect that the Liberal and National parties would have some appreciation of the difficulties in which the Government is placed in this respect and not find itself being assailed by the spokesman on a matter which is an interpretation of the policies pursued by the previous Government. Our attitude is to review the two airlines agreement. In those circumstances East- West might find that it has a case and that the Government is sympathetic towards the airline. But until that point has been reached the Government has no alternative but to deny the facilities, as has been stated by the Minister for Aviation, Mr Beazley.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMITTEE IN SUPPORT OF EAST TIMOR WITHIN THE AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General both in his own capacity and as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is there a committee called the 'Committee in Support of East Timor within the Australian Labor Party'? Did the Committee write to all branches in Victoria, in the latter half of last year following the ALP conference in July and call on the Labor Party federally to implement its policy on East Timor? Who are the members of the Committee, if it does exist? Who are the signatories to the letter? What is the policy to be implemented?

—I believe that that question is entirely out of order. It bears upon internal party organisational matters and has no relevance whatsoever to the conduct of the ministerial portfolio of the Minister whom I represent.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Finance seen a recent advertisement in the Australian Financial Review headed 'Tax Avoidance is alive and well in Aus!!!'? The advertisement states:

QUESTION.PARA: A complete four-cassette recording (6 hours) is now available of what was said at my recent Tax Survival Congress . . . hard-core, practical methods . . . how to delay your tax claim for at least five years . . . how to salvage your assets in the meanwhile . . . twelve new, proven, Hawke-proof ways to earn a tax-free income. How to kill a tax investigation.
Cheques ($250) to Dr Peter Clyne . . .

The advertisement gives an address. I ask the Minister: Even if the Government has to live with the decision of this House last night to allow $570m of revenue to be lost, will the Government do something to kill the effectiveness of those who continue to rip off the vast majority of Australian taxpayers and who make a living out of encouraging others to do the same? Alternatively, if tax avoidance is no longer alive and well, can the Government take action against Dr Clyne for false advertising?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen advertisements similar to the one referred to by Senator Coates. I do not know that I have seen that one. I understand that the heading 'Tax avoidance is alive and well' has been used in a lot of advertisements since the former discredited Treasurer of this country--
—Well done.

—I practised all night. The former Treasurer failed to take proper action against tax avoiders in this country. I dare say that after yesterday's performance in this place a new set of cassettes will come out containing excerpts of speeches by Opposition members in this place demonstrating to those who would indulge in tax evasion and tax avoidance that they still have friends within the Parliament. I think it is a pity that such advertisements should be produced in this country. I think it is appalling that this should be done for gain and in a public way. The Government has certainly been inhibited in its efforts to get at the tax evasion and tax avoidance industry. Those people opposite who frequently write to me urging that I should attack those on the unemployment benefit, those on the single parent's benefit and those on social security benefits in general, and make sure that they do not get too much, were willing to vote in here yesterday to allow a large number of people who can well afford it to get away with $500m. However, I will refer the detail of the question to the Minister for Finance to see whether something cannot be done to stop parasites like this preying on the rest of the community in the way that they have done.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that a Mr John Bowen has accompanied the Prime Minister as a senior adviser on his visit to Indonesia? Is this the same Mr John Bowen who, as an officer of the Office of National Assessments, in 1980 was censured and disciplined by the head of ONA for leaking 'ideas' for information being assembled by Mr Jim Dunn of the Parliamentary Library staff? Is it not common knowledge that Mr John Bowen and Mr Jim Dunn are close personal friends? Is not Mr Dunn well known for his strong criticism of the Government of Indonesia over East Timor? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether the Government believes that the Indonesians will discuss anything in confidence with the Prime Minister while he has Mr Bowen with him?

—I do not know whether Mr John Bowen is accompanying the Prime Minister on his trip to Indonesia. I will undertake to find out. But on the assumption that he is, I am able to answer certain other parts of the question. Firstly, I am able to say that it is common knowledge in this Parliament, I believe, that Mr Jim Dunn was opposed to the manner of incorporation within Indonesia of East Timor. If I might say so and offer an opinion, I think that Mr Dunn has been consistent and courageous in his position in relation to that matter. I would answer the other part of the question by saying that I do not believe that the Indonesian Government is so sensitive and so puerile that it would engage in a process of guilt by association of the kind which has been suggested in Senator Lewis's question.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLEGED DUMPING OF GOODS IN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the possibility of serious harm being caused to Australian industry by dumping of goods from overseas countries in Australia, what steps is the Minister taking to ensure that dumping complaints are dealt with more speedily?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable senator's question is highly topical, I suppose, as it turns out. There is widespread concern amongst many Australian industries about the impact of alleged dumping of exports from overseas countries in Australia. It has been a matter of quite continuous discussion I suppose for the last 18 months or so. That discussion has been very much engendered by the world recession, not only because of the effects of allegedly dumped goods in Australia but also because of the capacity of other countries, where they have industries working well below capacity because of the recession, to provide goods in Australia at considerably reduced prices.

ANSWER.PARA: Since this Government came to office it has undertaken and pursued a vigorous examination of anti-dumping provisions. Yesterday or the day before the Department of Industry and Commerce distributed a discussion paper to industry on the current dumping provisions and proposals for change of those provisions. The discussion paper has been widely circulated and officers of the Department this month will be discussing it with industry throughout Australia in the form of seminars and so on.

I draw Senator Elstob's attention to the fact that there are very different views about the dumping issue-one view I suppose being represented on one side by the National Farmers Federation and, on the other side, by particular industries which claim to be very much affected by dumping. We hope that review will be finalised within a month or so and the Government will then announce the position in relation to existing anti-dumping provisions. It is a matter of great concern and it is being dealt with as expeditiously as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It arises from what is becoming a common practice in the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales to insert in contracts for the sale of land, and in contracts for commercial conveyances, an option clause whereby if the Government introduces a capital gains tax in the August Budget, the vendors will have an option either to proceed with the completion of the sale or to rescind the contract. In the light of this, will the Minister confirm the Government's election promise that it will not introduce a new capital gains tax either directly or indirectly upon profits arising from sale of property? Is the Government giving any consideration whatsoever to a capital gains tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not giving any consideration to the introduction of a capital gains tax. The whole question of the imposition of taxes will have to be considered in the Budget context by the Government. The question of the introduction of a capital gains tax has not been considered by the Government since it was elected to office.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of the taxation package which the Government will have to look to in the Budget context may well have to be re-assessed as a result of a decision which was made in the Senate last night in relation to the tax recoupment legislation. As Senator Reid well knows, there was a very substantial loss of revenue as a result of the defeat of that legislation. That means that the Government will have to make a very vigorous assessment of how that--

TALK.START.PARA: —At least you might do it honestly this time.
—I do not know what that means. The Government will, in the Budget context, have to consider how that revenue is to be gained.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs: Is it a fact that there has been a recent substantial increase in the number of claims-claims related to new disabilities as well as service pension claims- lodged with the Department of Veterans' Affairs? What are the reasons for such an increase in claims? How is the Department coping with this increased work load?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a very substantial increase in the number of claims being received by my Department. I think that would flow from two basic reasons: Firstly, the decline in the economy-people being out of work and people being concerned about retrenchments-and, secondly, the age of veterans generally . With the sort of economic decline which has characteristed this country's behaviour over the last four or five years and the responsibilities which therefore rested on the previous Government, I think it is understandable that lots of people would be applying for some sort of government assistance. Veterans from any of the wars would obviously see an opportunity to place their claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for consideration. As I understand it, the number of veterans claiming disability pensions for the first time has increased by some 29 per cent. Other veterans with repatriation entitlements are claiming additional disabilities. Those claims have increased by something in excess of 31 per cent over the last year.

ANSWER.PARA: In recent times I have been asked several questions about service pension entitlements. That, of course, is related to what is happening in the employment area generally. Over the last year there has been an increase of some 27 per cent in the number of claims for service pensions. During a period of unemployment and economic downturn I think we would expect to see an increase. That increase has taken place in the 12-month period to about April. Clearly, that increase would have an economic influence. To that extent, of course, the previous Government is indicted for the failure of its policies over the last seven years.

In addition, a considerable amount of pressure is being exerted on the Department to extend the range of benefits to many veterans from overseas who have come to live in our country. That also indicates a growth in application numbers. All in all it can be said that it is envisaged that the substantial increase in the number of claims by veterans that we have had this year will continue next year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DRUIDS HOSPITAL AND MEDICAL BENEFITS FUND

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, who would be aware of the personal suffering of some former members of the failed Tasmanian Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund. Is the former Chairman of the Druids Medical and Hospital Benefits Fund the same gentleman who is now before the courts in relation to his handling of moneys relating to a Tasmanian shipping company? Were there any irregularities in the Fund's records? Were officers negligent in the discharge of their duties? What action did the Federal Department of Health take to identify and rectify the Fund's financial and liquidity problems over several years? Can the various government reports which have been prepared in relation to this Fund be released for public examination? Further, is it true that the funeral and death benefits fund under the Tasmanian Druids' umbrella is now in financial difficulties? Were moneys paid irregularly from one fund to another to give rise to this latest financial predicament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the difficulties that were created by the collapse of the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund and of Senator Watson's close interest in this matter. At that time many patients who were owed funds after being treated in hospitals and by local doctors, many hospitals that were owed funds and many doctors who were owed funds ended up in considerable difficulty. Some people had to sell assets to pay the bills that resulted. At that time Senator Watson, I and others in this place made inquiries of the Department of Health during both Question Time and Estimates committee hearings to try to find out what had happened. I accept that we never received a satisfactory response to most of our requests. Therefore, it is disturbing for me to find that, as Senator Watson has said, the former Chairman of the Fund is now in difficulties in another capacity because of his alleged mishandling of funds.

ANSWER.PARA: The Federal Department of Health had difficulties with Druids and other hospital benefits associations at the time, I believe as much because of their inability or lack of willingness to follow the existing regulations and legislation, as the necessity to demand from those hospital benefit funds the regular return of records which they should have provided. As a result of the difficulties of Druids, it is my understanding that there was a State and Federal inquiry. I think it was a combined State and Federal inquiry but there may have been two separate ones. I have tried, and it is my understanding that Senator Watson has tried since that time, to get the result of these inquiries and to get the reports which were issued at the time. We have been unsuccessful. In light of the new happenings, I will certainly approach the Minister for Health and ask him to see whether we cannot get one or both of those reports released.

If it is true that the funeral and death benefits fund run by Druids is in difficulty, if the rumours that that fund was used to prop up the hospital and medical fund for a time are true, I believe it is primarily a matter for the State Government, as the funeral and death benefits fund comes under the State Government. But I hope that with State and Federal co-operation on this occasion we will be able to get to the bottom of what I believe has been a very murky pool.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION ON INTELLIGENCE AND SECURITY AGENCIES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. During yesterday's debate on the first reading of a money Bill, I referred briefly to the Hope Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security Agencies and to pages 12 and 13 of the transcript of evidence. In view of the Commissioner's comments and the manner in which they were made, I ask the Attorney-General: Does he agree with those comments and the manner in which they were made? Do these comments and the manner in which they were made reflect upon the impartiality of the Commission? If so, what chance has Mr Combe and, for that matter, any other person who may be investigated by the Commission? I further ask: Are we about to witness a Petrov-type inquiry, this time under a Labor government, in which the main accuser stands remote and all evidence is not available to the person accused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The precise words of the Commissioner, to which Senator Georges referred yesterday and to which he refers more elliptically again today, were as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: A person can be a security risk without having committed any offence . . . I do not even know that you have to offend against a principle. But that is all a matter of submission later on.

I am asked in effect by Senator Georges to do two things: First, to expound on what the Commissioner meant by those words and, secondly, to sit in judgment on what he said. I propose to do neither. As has almost universally been accepted in public comment made since his appointment, there is no one better qualified in Australia than Mr Justice Hope to conduct the present inquiry and to conduct it thoroughly, fairly, and in the interests of all parties before it, including, of course, Mr Combe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Attorney- General did not refer to the manner in which the comments were made. They were made in interruption of the defence counsel. That interruption put a different aspect on the matter.
—I have nothing to add to my answer.

—I ask Senator Button, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question which I should like to have asked Senator Walsh, but he is not here. It concerns uranium mining. Is it not an act of hyprocrisy to object to the French Government testing nuclear devices in the Pacific but at the same time continue to export and sell our uranium overseas? In other words, we will continue to sell our uranium for use in nuclear weapons but it must be tested in someone else's backyard, not ours. Does it not in effect mean that? Why has the Government given authority for two companies, Energy Resources of Australia Ltd and Queensland Mines Ltd, to negotiate new contracts to, in the words of the Minister for Trade, '. . . maintain a presence in that market'? Why would it be necessary for this Australian Labor Party Government to allow new contracts to be negotiated to maintain a presence in the uranium market if ALP policy is to desist from the signing of new contracts and the continued export of uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has made quite clear on many occasions, and will continue to do so, its opposition to French nuclear tests in the Pacific. I think it is fair to say that the Government agrees with the implication in Senator Chipp's question that if the French Government wishes to test nuclear weapons, it should at least do so in its own back pool rather than in ours. The question of whether there is a nexus between the continuance of supply to a French electricity authority-under existing contractual arrangements between various French companies and the French Government-and the question of putting pressure on the French Government to abandon nuclear tests in the Pacific is a matter of judgment. A number of aspects need to be weighed. By implication Senator Chipp makes a judgment which is perhaps different from that of the Government. The Government is examining all aspects of uranium policy.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the supplying of electricity power utilities in the United States, to which the honourable senator refers, it is not correct to say that the Government has authorised either of the two companies mentioned to enter into contracts in that regard. I understand that the companies have been allowed to resume negotiations with the American electricity power utilities but, of course , the question of any contractual arrangements is a matter for subsequent examination in the light of the general review of existing arrangements regarding the export of uranium.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. To quote Senator Walsh, what is the point of allowing these two companies to resume negotiations with certain electric power utilities in the United States if the Government-after those negotiations have been resumed-vetoes the conclusion of any contract? What is the point in allowing negotiations if, at the bottom line the Government is going to say: 'No more contracts'?

—I am unable to comment on the history of the negotiations. I very much suspect that the continuance of those negotiations might be affected by what has taken place in the past. As I am unable to give a precise answer to that question I will direct it to the Minister for Trade and obtain an answer for Senator Chipp.

—Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the impact on Australian automotive components manufacturers of continued expansion of the export facilitation scheme, including recent cancellations of $22m worth of car parts contracts? In view of the serious state of the car industry in South Australia, what does the Minister plan to do to limit any ill effects caused by the scheme? Will he indicate whether he will go to Adelaide to see the problems of the car industry there at first hand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very well aware of the concern amongst sections of the automotive components parts manufacturing industry about the impact of the export facilitation scheme. I am aware also of their concern about the effect that that scheme is having and could continue to have on their operations. In fairness, I have to say that while that scheme is affecting some component parts manufacturers adversely, benefits do flow to other component parts manufacturers by virtue of its operation. I will refer to a situation of which Senator Maguire as a South Australian senator will be aware. The benefits of the scheme to the Mitsubishi company and certain component part manufacturers have been positive.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no question of terminating the export facilitation scheme. I make that clear. There has never been any suggestion by the Australian Labor Party, in opposition or in government, that the scheme should be terminated. There is a very real need for the motor car industry to improve its competitiveness, both in its interest and in the interests of consumers. Whatever one does with the operation of the scheme, there will be different views within the industry about the benefits which it gives and, in some cases, the detriment which it causes. The honourable senator will not need reminding that, prior to the election, the Government indicated that it would re-examine the decision of the previous Government to extend the export facilitation scheme to 15 per cent from the present limit of 7 1/2 per cent. There is a great diversity of opinion on that issue within the industry. It is a matter upon which the Government hopes to reach a decision, probably later this month, after discussions with various interests representing various parts of the industry at the Automotive Industry Advisory Council. I have been asked by the honourable senator whether I will visit Adelaide to discuss the motor car industry with representatives of the industry in South Australia. I will be going to Adelaide next week and having discusions with the South Australian Government and with interests representing various parts of the motor vehicle industry regarding that matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is prompted by the information he gave earlier in response to Senator Giles. I now ask: Is the Minister in a position to clarify the position of repatriation pensioners following the introduction of the new Medicare program? Will they be affected by the levy? Is he able to clarify their position?

—I think I spoke last week, in reply to a question from Senator Reid, on the question of the levy as it applies to veterans. No levy will apply to average beneficiaries under the Repatriation Act. Specifically, discussions are taking place between the Department of Health, the Department of Social Security and the Department of Veterans' Affairs to work out precisely the cut- off point for those in receipt of substantial incomes. For example, if members of parliament received a disability pension, I do not think it could be argued that they should be exempt from the levy. Those sorts of matters are still under discussion. They will be resolved in time-certainly before the Budget. I assure the Senate and Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle that 99 per cent of average beneficiaries of repatriation pensions will not have to pay the levy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I wish to ask a brief supplementary question. Will those entitled to free medical care at present be affected by the levy?

—Nobody will be disadvantaged as result of the Government's approach to these matters. I assure the Senate that the Government is determined that those who suffered as a result of their war service will not be affected in any way.
