SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill has two major purposes-firstly, to abolish the Industrial Relations Bureau and, secondly, to facilitate union amalgamations. Both subjects are well enough known to the Senate and to the people of Australia that I need not explain further the purpose of the Bill. In any event, its purpose has been set out clearly enough in the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). The Opposition supports the Bill as a whole. It supports both the abolition of the Industrial Relations Bureau and the principle of facilitating union amalgamations.

SPEECH.PARA: The Industrial Relations Bureau was, of course, set up by the Fraser Government . I believe it had a very important purpose indeed; namely, to ensure an even- handed enforcement of the conciliation and arbitration laws. During the years the Fraser Government was in office it passed a number of very important laws to protect individual members of unions against the overweening powers of unions which had been acquired both legally and outside the law. Unfortunately the union movement has claimed to be outside the law. As far as I can see, the policy of the Labor Government is to facilitate the freeing of the union movement from any restrictions of the law. This Bill does not deal with any of those major issues, which no doubt will be the subject of very considerable debate in the Parliament so long as the Labor Government is in office because I have no doubt that it will propose various amendments to the Act in the future which will weaken the provisions which protect the public from the overweening powers of militant and rampant unionism. Those are matters which we will address in the future. Fortunately we do not have to address them this afternoon. The Industrial Relations Bureau was an instrument created by the Fraser Government for the purpose of seeking an even-handed enforcement of the conciliation and arbitration laws not only against employers who breach or may be suspected of breaching awards but also against unions which seek to breach the rights of individuals guaranteed by a number of amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act which were largely the product of the Fraser Government.

It appears from the evidence made available to us that the Industrial Relations Bureau has not been effective in the way intended. On that basis the Opposition will not oppose now the abolition of that Bureau. However, one very important matter remains; that is, there should be an adequate body to protect the rights created by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, of individuals who inevitably find themselves from time to time in conflict with the unions and, as I said, the overweening exercise of union power. The legislation provides that the power to enforce the law against breaches of awards by employers and the investigation of those breaches of awards should be restored to the Arbitration Inspectorate. That will be under the auspices of the Minister, as it was before the Industrial Relations Bureau was set up. That is all very well and I hope it will work effectively. As I understand it, the other powers of the Industrial Relations Bureau will be largely conferred on the Industrial Registrar. I would like the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button)-when he stops talking to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) who is distracting his attention from this debate at the moment-to assure us in his reply that adequate resources will be given to the Industrial Registrar and that the Industrial Registrar has adequate powers remaining under the Act adequately to enforce the law against unions, as well as the power to move against employers which is provided in this Bill.

The other aspect of this Bill which I mention briefly is the facilitation of union amalgamations. The present situation is that unions can amalgamate only if 50 per cent of the enrolled union membership vote for an amalgamation. A simple majority of members is required. That provision has created a number of problems for unions that want to amalgamate. It is very difficult to get 50 per cent of the actual membership to vote on the question. Although that may be an interesting commentary on the way in which unions operate and the extent to which unions operate and the extent to which unions are really subject to democratic control by their members, nevertheless, we accept the fact that major practical difficulties have occurred.

Therefore, this legislation proposes that that provision should be modified to enable the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission at its discretion to make a declaration that certain unions have sufficient community of interest to justify their amalgamation. If the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is so satisfied and makes a declaration accordingly, a minimum 25 per cent of the total membership is required to vote-fortunately to that extent, the democratic control is retained-on the question. But it also provides that there should be only a simple majority. That would mean, therefore, that an amalgamation could be agreed to by a union even though only 12 1/2 per cent of the members of the union agreed to it. The Opposition is very concerned by that provision. Indeed, I hope the Senate will be concerned by it also.

As the Senate will be aware, a very important Senate select commitee reported to the Senate in October 1982. That Committee was presided over by Senator Harradine who is, as we all know, an expert on matters relating to unions as, indeed, he is on many other subjects. But his particular experience has been in the union movement. He was the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. That Committee also comprised three Australian Labor Party senators including Senator Button who is the Minister in charge of this Bill today and who is proposing in this Bill a matter which is rather different, as I will explain, from the recommendations of that Committee and to which, as a member of that Committee, he agreed without dissent. Senator Bolkus who is not sufficiently interested in this subject to be in the chamber this afternoon was a member of that Committee. Senator Siddons, of the Australian Democrats, who unfortunately is not present because of the will of the electors at the recent elections, was also a member. He represented the Democrats on this Committee. So I assume there is no suggestion that the Democrats will not support the recommendations of that Committee. Three other very distinguished senators were also members of the Committee-Senator Reg Withers, Senator Walters and Senator Hamer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Senator Withers?

—He will be here at the right moment, Senator; do not worry about that. He will be here when the test is made. I want to read what the Senate Select Committee said about union amalgamations. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence was given to the Committee which persuades it to acknowledge the present difficulties posed by the Act in cases where members of separate unions have reasonably expressed a desire to effect an amalgamation of their union.
The Opposition accepts that. The report continues:

The Committee, however, does not favour legislation which would allow for uninhibited amalgamations, and considers that amalgamations should only take place after a 'community of interest' test has been satisfied.
The Bill provides for that, and we support it. The Committee stated:
The Committee is also of the view that the membership of unions proposing to amalgamate must be consulted and given an opportunity to express a view thereon.
We agree with that and the Bill provides for it. The Committee also went on to say:

The Committee suggests that in elections where the membership is consulted on mergers, at least 25 per cent of the membership of each union should be required to record a vote, and of those voting, at least two thirds should be required to vote in favour of the proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has Senator Button read that?

—Yes, he was a member of the Committee. This is a unanimous view and recommendation of the Committee. We should not forget the Australian Democrat member of the Committee, Senator Siddons, who also agreed with the recommendation that at least two-thirds of the membership of each union should be required to vote in favour of the proposition. An alternative proposal that the Committee stated was:

SPEECH.PARA: An alternative could be for at least 25 per cent of the total membership of each union to vote in favour of amalgamation, provided that those voting in favour constitute a majority of the votes cast.

The Opposition believes that there certainly should be an amendment to the existing law relating to union amalgamations. The existing law has been too rigorous and has prevented useful and justifiable amalgamations. Therefore we support the principle of the Bill, but in the Committee stage we will seek to amend it. An amendment has been circulated on behalf of the Opposition which will give effect to the Committeee's first recommendation, namely, that in order to approve an amalgamation there must be a certificate from the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and a voting majority of 25 per cent of the members of the unions involved. At least a two-thirds majority is required.

I do not want to detain the Senate at any length on this subject. It is important that where amalgamations are under consideration a reasonable number of union members should take sufficient interest in it to vote. It is very common in any organisation, whether it be companies, unions or ordinary societies, that on major issues matters are not decided by simple majorities but by something like a two-thirds or even in some cases a three-quarters majority of those voting to support the proposition. It is a very common provision. I think the Senate Committee showed its recognition of this. Senator Button, who is seeking to interject in a somewhat inconsequential manner, recognised that fact as well. The Opposition will move an amendment accordingly. At this stage we support the principle of the Bill and its second reading and we hope it will be agreed to by the Senate without undue delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute to the debate this afternoon although I appreciate that in the circumstances-it is the final day of sitting-I should be brief. If economic recovery is to come to Australia one element must be better, industrial relations. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1982 over 2.1 million working days were lost through industrial disputes. The figure in the previous year was nearly 4.2 million days lost. The fact that it is considerably lower than the 6.2 million days lost at the high point of the previous Labor regime in 1974, when the now Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and President of the Australian Labor Party, is little consolation. The figure remains beyond that which Australia can afford and it affects all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: In this highly competitive world the efficient and the productive will prosper. Industrial turmoil is just one further hindrance to efficiency. Therefore to limit areas of conflict is a desirable objective and that is the way that I have approached the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1983. As Senator Durack said, it is a Bill to contribute to the objective, firstly, abolishing the Industrial Relations Bureau and returning to the Industrial Inspectorate and , secondly, by facilitating union amalgamation where a community of interest between unions exists.

I am told that the IRB is seen as perpetuating the ideological conflict between employer and employee. Whilst I am somewhat sceptical of the logical merit of that argument, as it appears that the new Industrial Inspectorate will have principally the same responsibilities, nevertheless, in a situation where both the employers and employees want change, as evidenced by the recommendations of the National Labour Consultative Council, I would anticipate government to respond unless cogent reasons exist to the contrary.

The Government's principal responsibility is to the public at large. However, to lessen strains between parties in industrial relations, less ideological conflict between employers and employees will be of public benefit. Whilst I must confess that I do not see this as in any way a major reform, I accept the change in the spirit of the advice I have-that it will be a small positive step to breaking down confrontationist attitudes. I must say also that I view the proposals to ease the restrictions upon amalgamation of unions where a community of interest exists in much the same way. If the proposals can have the effect of easing inter and intra union conflict, the price of which is suffered by the whole community, or can improve the efficiency of our industrial relations processes, the provisions deserve support.

There are seven claimed difficulties arising within industry as a result of the existence of the current structure of trade unionism, which of course consists of over 300 unions, principally and historically craft or trade based. Those seven reasons were referred to the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation last year by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. A further two reasons were put by employer groups. As the reasons are conveniently listed in the Senate committee's report, I will not go through them in detail. However, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the reasons as stated in the report.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT AND INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS REASONS
(1) demarcation disputes between unions with overlapping eligibility for membership rules;
(2) inefficient use of the finite resources available to Australian trade unions from what are presently often small and fragmented memberships;

(3) problems in negotiations between employers and trade unions as to terms and conditions of employment arising from the multiplicity of trade unions not only within an industry but often a particular enterprise;
(4) lack of identification by trade unions which have a membership in several industries with the interests of a given industry;

(5) rigidity in the structure of an industry's workforce arising from the understandable reluctance of unions to accept workers moving from their area of coverage to that of other unions within the industry;
(6) the possibility of flow on of wage levels appropriate to one industry to another industry without proper consideration of their appropriateness in the context of the second industry; and
(7) the possibility of wage leap frogging within an industry resulting from the multiplicity of trade unions.
EMPLOYER GROUPS REASONS
(1) Competition between trade unions to secure better wages and working conditions for their members in the same industry or enterprise, leading to instability in industrial relations; and
(2) The inability of trade unions and employers in particular industries and enterprises to develop a common understanding of the realities facing that industry or enterprise.
(See CAI Evidence, pp. 1091-92)

TALK.START.PARA: —The major claim is that amalgamation will reduce demarcation disputes about which membership will perform certain work and jurisdictional conflicts over coverage of workers in a firm or industry. The Australian Bureau of Statistics does not keep figures on days lost through demarcation disputes but rather provides the general causal head of trade unionism. In the last full year for which figures are available, 1981, 87,400 working days were lost under that head. In the previous year 103,400 working days were lost. The Senate select committee took evidence from the Federated Clerks Union of Australia which argued that days lost attributable to demarcation disputes in the seven- year-period 1973-79 were no more than 3 per cent of working days lost in any one year. One commentator, however, J. Niland, estimates that about 8 per cent of all strikes in Australia result from demarcation problems and a further 5 per cent are intra-union in nature. Conditionally Professor Brian Brooks, of the University of New South Wales Law School, in a paper 'Trade Union Amalgamation', said:

SPEECH.PARA: With rapid technological change the incidence of demarcation disputes arising from eligibility clauses is certain to increase.

It seems not unreasonable to assume that amalgamation will reduce certain inter- union strike activity. It might be assuming too much, however, to expect that tensions between different groups of workers now covered by separate unions would disappear with amalgamation. Intra-union problems may increase. However, this Bill deals with amalgamations where a community of interest already exists. Therefore, from the point of view of demarcation and jurisdictional disputes there appears to be potential for amalgamation for a reduction in disputes which , whilst not a major cause of time lost, is, nevertheless, a significant cause.

The second of the major problems claimed to be overcome by amalgamation is a reduction in difficulties from multi-unionism. The assertion is that negotiations are made more difficult by the need to involve larger groups and more people than would be the case with a single union entity within a designated bargaining or negotiating orbit. We should however, be warned on this subject by David Gill in his article 'Industry Unions-Policy or Pipedream?' appearing in the Journal of Industrial Relations. It states:

General amalgamations might reduce fragmentation in the aggregate terms but their end product might simply be fewer, large factions still organized on the present haphazard basis thereby perpetuating, even entrenching, the weaknesses that amalgamations are supposed to overcome.

This brings us again back to the community of interest prerequisite in the Bill for the less stringent amalgamation proposals. The Bill may lead to a few extra amalgamations. If so, it would lead to a slight reduction in multi-unionism and as the unions being amalgamated already have a community of interest, it may reduce marginally the complexity of negotiation. It is difficult to place the merit, however, on a stronger basis. It seems reasonable to assume that some further rationalisation of multi-unionism could result in better use of resources and an improvement in operating efficiency. Even that does not necessarily follow.

It must be remembered that unions are not bodies created by law but rather bodies which have grown out of a need. Howard Gill and Vivien Griffin in another article 'The Fetish of Order: Reform in Australian Union Structure' stated:
Unions must be the source not the object of reform.

A superior being cannot restructure the union movement according to some grand plan. But there are difficulties in the system for which the public suffer which appear capable of being lessened by certain amalgamations where a community of interest exists. The Bill in no way directs amalgamation, it simply facilitates such amalgamations and only in a small way by easing the minimum voting requirements. The union movement has, and will, remain largely cautious of amalgamation presumably because of loss of vested interests; conservatism, with workers feeling greater affinity for bodies specifically representing their particular occupation or skill category; or for other reasons. There has been little spontaneous movement towards sensible amalgamations.

There is a responsibility upon those in the industrial relations arena, particularly the Australian Council of Trade Unions, to encourage such amalgamations as can improve the system and reduce community loss. Similarly, there is a responsibility on the Parliament to ensure laws that enable such amalgamations to proceed as are beneficial without undue obstacles whilst, on the other hand, providing reasonable security to the interests of particular unionists. That security lies in the minimum voting requirements.

Beneficial amalgamations have not taken place under the existing provisions which were introduced in 1972. The numbers required appear too difficult to achieve. Some relaxation, therefore, seems desirable. Where the line is drawn is a matter for judgment. The rationale of the intended Opposition amendments, which are to accept relaxation to the extent recommended by the Senate Select Committee last year, is to proceed cautiously. When one is talking of the structure of industrial relations, that is an approach with merit.

The reforms in the Bill will not, by their mere existence, improve industrial relations. As the Senate Select Committee said last year: 'there is considerable doubt among the industrial community that union structures predominately determine industrial relations outcomes'. The reforms can, however, facilitate improvement when there are goodwill and a common recognition that Australia, if it is to prosper in this competitive world, cannot afford the industrial relations failures of the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are 100 per cent in favour of the retention and the strengthening of unions because unions are basic to this country's conciliation and arbitration system. Historically, employers have preferred to deal with representative organisations rather than negotiate with individuals. So it stands to reason that there is a need and support throughout the community for the unions to be better organised to be able more fully and appropriately to represent the people on whose behalf they speak. Practically, of course, large employer organisations with hundreds or thousands of employees need representative bodies. Therefore, it is important for us to make for easier amalgamations of unions in any way that that can be achieved. We suffer in this country from the proliferation of unions, some of them minute. Nevertheless, despite their inconsequence in terms of numbers they may wield great power and do great damage to this community. Therefore we would have been very keen to see go through the amendment that I had proposed to move, as this would haved eased the way for the amalgamation of those unions whose interested, concerned and involved members are willing to support such amalgamations. We believe that the original constraints that were placed on those unions, particularly in terms of voting numbers, were too hard for bodies which frequently are widely dispersed and need to be given the opportunity to bring about these amalgamations without having to canvass several thousand members spread widely across Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats support the principle of reduced voting proportions which will come about as a result of the passage of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1983. It will allow for easier amalgamations.

I also mention just briefly that we are quite happy with the replacement of the Industrial Relations Bureau. Its establishment was a politically motivated move at the time. An organisation was set up which-irrespective of whether it was originally conceived to do so-was perceived by many people in the community, particularly the trade unions, as being a union-bashing organisation. We can do without that from either side of the industrial field.

I think it is important for us to recognise also that the rights of unions to act to improve the conditions of their members are essential in this community. But I am aware also of other important rights that have to be preserved in a democracy. I hope that the spirit of consensus and compromise that emerged from the National Economic Summit Conference continues to thrive. It is in this spirit-the need for employees and employers to co-operate so as to increase the living standards of all Australians-that I support this Bill.

Nevertheless, compulsory union membership is to some people a fundamental attack on their liberties. We cannot be free to do everything we want to do; society imposes necessary constraints on its members. We are, therefore, not free to drive on which ever side of the road that takes our fancy. There are other areas where individual freedoms can be extended. I would like to extend the liberty of individuals in Australia without denying unions their legitimate right to contribute to industrial relations in Australia.

I believe that a democratic society should be able to provide for both the rights of the individual and the rights of the unions. At the moment, we provide for the rights of unions-I concur with this-but do not allow people who object to joining unions the liberty to make a choice without there being a great deal of emotion and conflict between those individuals and the union concerned. When they make the wrong choice from the union's point of view industrial disputes occur. The union demands compulsory membership and, in many cases, acts to close down any firm that employs non-union members. This, of course, causes industrial dislocation and may even result in the collapse of the firm.

SPEECH.PARA: The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill does not deal just with the amalgamation situation. It also abolishes the Industrial Relations Bureau. I have no problems with that at all. I am very happy that it has been abolished. It never had the teeth to undertake the work that was asked of it. Its main problem was that it was unable to cope with the rights of the individual. I quote from pages 19 to 21 of the Bureau's annual report, which lists the rights of individuals under the present legislation. It states:

S.5 prohibits employers from dismissing or disadvantaging employees because of particular activities associated with their organisation membership, their award rights or their refusal to participate in industrial action.
S.132A prohibits discriminatory action by an organisation against an independent contractor who does not belong to the organisation.

That is the area that I want to address in the next few minutes. The Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) may not be aware-even though I am sure people have approached him on this-of the tremendous problems of owner- drivers in Australia-those who own their own trucks-who are under contract. They are not employees. The Transport Workers Union of Australia at the moment-I can speak only for my State-intimidates those owner-drivers and forces them to join that union. Two years ago the unions were told by the court to delete from their award all guidelines concerning the recruitment of such owner-drivers. They were forced to do that but have since ignored altogether the court's order. The situation in my State now is that the union seeks actively to recruit owner- drivers. When owner-drivers say to the union officials: 'You cannot do anything for me. Your awards say that there is no reason for me to become a member; indeed you cannot represent me', the answer given is: 'If you do not, your truck will not move. We will black ban you from the wharves. We will not load your trucks. We will make sure that the members of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia neither load nor unload your trucks.' This sort of intimidation has been occurring certainly throughout my State and in other areas of Australia also. I appeal to the Minister at least to alter this section of the Bill to give the new Industrial Arbitration Inspectorate the right to enforce the law in this regard and allow these owner-drivers to enjoy their rights under law.

Clause 12 of the Bill relates to the definition of 'amalgamation'. The Government has said that the amalgamation of unions has been too difficult, that unions have found that they cannot make out a good enough case to encourage the majority of their members to participate in a ballot. It is suggested that the present 50 per cent requirement be reduced in certain instances-such as where a community of interest has been shown-so that only 25 per cent of members need vote and half of that number plus one, voting in favour, may decide the issue. Thus, if only 12.5 per cent of union members vote in favour of amalgamation it can then take place. Where else in a democracy can 12.5 per cent of the members of any organisation decide that the organisation will be abolished? It just is not done. The unions' only response to this is to make sure to spend as much money as the hierarchy will allow in order to encourage members to vote against amalgamation, if that is what they want to do. I am not against amalgamation, particularly if there be a community of interest.

Senator Durack referred to the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation, of which Senator Harradine was chairman and Senator Bolkus, Senator Button, Senator Mulvihill, Senator Siddons, Senator Withers and myself were members. That Committee came down with a unanimous report in one area. At the time Senator Button agreed, as did the representative of the Australian Democrats, that the most equitable way to go about this was to agree with the union representatives that only 25 per cent of members of a union need vote but that two-thirds of that 25 per cent must vote in favour of amalgamation before it was passed. That is not much to ask. Indeed, it was agreed with the National Labour Consultative Council. The report from our Committee was unanimous in that respect. But instead of the Government adopting that recommendation, with which its leader in this place agreed, of the Committee of which its leader in this place was a member, it has gone for a 12 1/2 per cent vote of a union. I believe that is most undemocratic.

I turn to the amendments that the Democrats have withdrawn. I was pleased to see the Democrats bring in the amendments because, while quite honestly I do not think they go far enough, they are better than nothing. There were three pages of amendments. They extended the rights of people to conscientious objection. Many people appeared before our Committee. Many people have said to me that although they belong to a union that is affiliated with a political party with which they do not agree, they do not see why they should have to pay full membership. The Committee, and Senator Button at that time, thought that this was a reasonable request.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was not the view of people who came before the Committee.

—How would the people who think that have got there? They were not invited as individuals. We saw only the union representatives. Does Senator Button really think that the union representatives would put that to us? The Committee came down with a recommendation which I will read to the chamber:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee acknowledges the need to retain the status of conscientious objection to union membership which is presently provided for in section 144A.
I would like the Democrats to take note of this because it was the particular hobby-horse of Senator Siddons. The recommendation continues:

However it believes that a less fundamental objection to union membership also be recognised, namely that a person holds principles or beliefs which prevent membership of unions. The Committee considers that such persons should be entitled to be exempted from membership provided that they contribute a fee for the services provided by the appropriate union . . .
It was acknowledged on our Committee that unions do an industrial relations job for all the members working in a particular area. The recommendation continues:

This fee would be settled in each case by the Industrial Registrar. It would be based on the standard membership fee which would be reduced by a maximum of ten per cent to take account of contributions made by the union to political parties and other expenditures which were unrelated to the direct provision of industrial or welfare services to members. The fee for service could only be applied by the union for the provision of industrial or welfare services. The Committee recommends that section 144A should be amended to recognise this alternative ground of objection to union membership.

That came across very clearly on our Committee because we found, for instance, that members of the Waterside Workers Federation boycotted ships travelling to a country to which they had some objection. Do the people of Australia know that on each ship there is a double crew, that each person who works on a ship works for only six months of the year? He has 17 days on and 17 days off, and so on, or whatever is the turn-about of the ship. He is working for only six months in the year. In this stupid nation we have to put up with people working for only six months in the year and taking an enormous annual salary. The salary may not appear to be high when one looks at it in the initial stages, but then one adds all the perks . One adds the fact that such people work a span of longer than nine hours, or they work some other arrangement, or they work overtime here or there, or because they are on for 17 days straight they are entitled to some extra perk because they did not get a holiday during that 17 days straight. There is no talk about the next 17 days that they have off. Because of all those perks, they are earning fantastic sums of money-$30,000 or $40,000 a year. It is far more than back bench members of parliament are getting paid.

In this nation we have to put up with that. It is destroying the nation. This sort of legislation will only assist in bringing about the destruction of the nation. It will not help in any way to bring about peace in industry. It will create bigger and bigger organisations which will do more and more harm to the nation. I should like to see the unions get back to a situation in which people who have a trade are entitled to be paid for the skill that they have. But look what happens nowadays with some companies. Consider a fellow who has been a turner and fitter for 20 or 30 years with a company. His son, aged 18, comes along and gets a job with the company, and when they take home their wages they find that dad is getting about $5 a week more than his son who is a labourer on the floor. That is because unions have organised to lower the wages of tradesmen and to bring up the wages of the unskilled, again to the detriment of our nation . The skilled people of this nation ought to be being paid for their skills, but they cannot be paid for their skills while we have organisations such as these growing, getting larger. That will be the result of this sort of legislation.

I pass on to make just minor mention of some of the intrigue, some of the ballot techniques that are adopted, and some of the problems that occur with balloting. I can recall reading Dr Evatt's proposal on this matter. There was some merit in it. I recommend it to the Labor Party for consideration. Dr Evatt proposed that if he had become Prime Minister-thank the Lord he never did-every year on a fixed date there would have been an election for union officials and the ballot would have been conducted by officers of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Labor Party ought to consider the merits of that proposal, which is worthy of considerable thought, rather than this sort of nonsense which achieves nothing except to enable unions which wish to amalgamate to do so more quickly and to get larger and larger to the detriment of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak very briefly in this debate on the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill because I believe that the outcome of this legislation is a foregone conclusion, as is the outcome of the amendment and/or amendments before us. I speak briefly also because I do not believe that this is a major piece of legislation on industrial relations. It may prove, one way or the other, some of the quite emotional furphies that have been put around over a period of years about the need for amalgamations to cut down on industrial disputes. It will be quite enlightening to see just what effect this legislation has on industrial disputes. Evidence was received by the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation which indicated quite clearly that the multiplicity of unions was a minuscule contribution to the overall incidence of industrial disputes. I point out to the Senate that what has been said in relation to the question of amalgamations was covered very clearly and adequately by the Senate Select Committee's recommendations. I address myself only to that aspect for the time being because the Senate has heard me speak before on the Industrial Relations Bureau and I do not wish to delay the Senate by repeating what I have said.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to amalgamation, the Bill proposes to reduce from 50 per cent to 25 per cent the membership vote necessary for an amalgamation ballot to be valid. The Committee received evidence that the current 50 per cent threshold requirement for members in a union to be able to vote in an amalgamation ballot was very difficult to achieve. In particular, we received evidence to that effect from the Australian Textile Workers Union and the Australian Boot Trade Employees Federation. From memory-I speak only from memory-in the amalgamation proposal advanced by those two unions the voting threshold achieved was something like 46 per cent but something like 90 per cent of those who voted voted in favour of amalgamation. The points made by both unions on that occasion included not only the problem of threshold but also the problem of the electoral roll.

The 12 months provision under the current legislation means, of course, that in the case of the textile industry and the boot trades industry, where there is a fairly substantial turnover of labour, many persons have been entitled to vote in amalgamation ballots who were not even in the industry at the time the ballot took place. Of course, that matter concerned the Committee. I am pleased to say that the new legislation reflects the recommendations made by the Committee in respect of that matter. I remind honourable senators that we suggested that the roll be updated before the ballot takes place. I commend the Government for including such a provision in this legislation.

I am somewhat perturbed that under the provisions of this legislation the threshold is to drop quite dramatically from 50 per cent to 25 per cent. I believe the principle governing our consideration of this legislation should be democratic control. The objects of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act endorse the principle of democratic control of organisations registered under the Act. I ask the Senate whether this Bill falls within that principle of democratic control. I suggest that it does not because under the legislation now before us an amalgamation could be endorsed by only 12 1/2 per cent, plus one, of the entire membership of a union. That does not fit well with the concept of democratic control of an organisation.

The proposal put forward by the Senate Select Committee recognised the practical difficulties experienced by, for example, the Australian Boot Trades Employees Federation and the Textile Workers Union in maintaining the principle of democratic control. Apart from the updating of the roll, one of the Committee 's recommendations was:

The Committee is also of the view that the membership of unions proposing to amalgamate must be consulted and given an opportunity to express a view thereon. The Committee suggests that in elections where the membership is conducted on mergers, at least 25 per cent of the membership of each union should be required to record a vote, and of those voting, at least two-thirds should be required to vote in favour of the proposition.

An alternative proposal put forward by the Committee was that a vote of 25 per cent of the total membership in favour of the proposed amalgamation be required. At least those two propositions placed this vital and fundamental question facing unions in a much higher category than any other proposition that may go to the rank and file for endorsement-for example, some sort of referendum. Even with referenda conducted under the Commonwealth Constitution there are safeguards. A mere majority of voters throughout the Commonwealth cannot change the basic constitution under which this Parliament operates and under which Australia as a whole operates. Certain provisions must be fulfilled; namely, because of the rights of the States within the Commonwealth a majority of votes must be recorded in a majority of States. Quite frequently referenda proposals have been lost despite the fact that a majority of voters in Australia has favoured the proposition. The same situation ought to apply in respect of unions .

One of the problems is the different structure of unions. Not all unions are structured on the basis of State branches. So the majority principle should be applied in such a way that it is appropriate to all forms of union structure. That is one of the reasons the Committee made the suggestion that it did. For example, the whole membership of a State branch of a union could be very vigourously opposed to amalgamation. Yet, because of the greater numbers in, say , Victoria and New South Wales, those States might carry the day. That is somewhat recognised by the fact that a number of union rules state that it is not possible for the constitutional rule to be amended unless two-thirds of the rule-making body-admittedly it is the rule-making body and not the rank and file -endorses such a proposal.

In those circumstances if it is good enough for such a rule to apply in respect of part of the eligibility rule, why is that principle not good enough when it comes to the question of the union going out of existence altogether and being amalgamated into another body? Those were the factors which exercised the minds of the members of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. If the recommendations of the Committee were adopted, the amalgamation of the Australian Boot Trades Employees Federation and the Textile Workers Union would fall within and easily meet that requirement because, as I mentioned, 46 per cent or thereabouts of the membership voted-even on the old membership roll which was 12 months behind-and about 90 per cent of that number voted in favour of it. Although the amalgamation was not able to be effected under current legislation, it would be under the proposals set out in the Senate Select Committee report. I point that out in very brief terms just for the record in the hope that, although I understand that this legislation is required now for a particular purpose, the Government may still keep in the back of its mind the recommendations made by the Senate Select Committee.

I come very briefly to the points that were made by Senator Walters in respect of preference and conscientious objection. I emphasise that the Committee examined this very thoroughly. But I believe that somewhat of a misunderstanding was exhibited in the honourable senator's speech when she seemed to consider that a proposed amendment would have fallen within the boundaries of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee. In my view, it would not, because the Committee said:

Some individuals are quick to recognize their perceived rights but are not also as quick to recognize their duty to associate with others for the common good. In addition there is a distinction between personal choice based on conscientious belief on the one hand and the dictates of self-centred individualism on the other . . .
The Committee went on to say, in words which were mulled over considerably:
The Committee acknowledges the need to retain the status of conscientious objection to union membership which is presently provided for in section 144A.
Because the Committee comprised a number of people from both sides and various opinions, the amalgam of their views was stated as such:

However it believes that a less fundamental objection to union membership should also be recognised, namely that a person holds principles or beliefs which prevent membership of unions. The Committee considers that such persons should be entitled to be exempted from membership provided that they contribute a fee for the services provided by the appropriate union, to that union. This fee would be settled in each case by the Industrial Registrar.

There were provisions along those lines. I think there has been some misconception by some honourable senators of what the Committee actually meant in its recommendations. For the record I place that comment before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. Some views have been very strongly expressed. Having served on the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation, I have had the benefit of hearing some of the strong views before. I make acknowledgements that relate to two key issues in this legislation. I acknowledge that there are, of course, differences of opinion about these matters. There have been these differences and there will probably always be these differences. Senator Harradine, in relation to the amalgamation provisions, invited the Government to look again at the report of the Committee which he chaired. We will do that. I give him that undertaking in the context that the Committee which he chaired was looking at a piece of legislation on this issue in the context of industry union amalgamations. As I am instructed, the Committee report has not been considered by the National Labour Consultative Council in the more general light of the changes that are now in this Bill in relation to the previous definition of 'industry unions' or 'enterprise unions' as they were called. So, we will look at that issue again. I appreciate the differences of view which have been expressed.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the matter raised by Senator Jack Evans, there were a number of very serious technical objections to the amendment proposed by him. Those technical objections would require amendments to numerous other sections of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. I have given the undertaking to Senator Jack Evans and the Australian Democrats that the technical matters in relation to that will be examined and that the issue of the right to opt out, as it were, on the basis of a payment of a fee, on which Senator Harradine commented, will be examined in conjunction with those parties who are concerned about how that provision might be better improved in a technical way and other ways in the future.

I do not wish to comment about a number of the substantive issues in the legislation. Perhaps the two issues which have been of most concern and which have caused the greatest degree of dissension have been amalgamations and the so -called extensions of the conscientious objection provision. They are matters about which we have some dispute. They are matters in respect of which I gave certain undertakings. Having said that, I thank the Senate for its general support of the Bill and particularly those parties from the Opposition with whom we in the Opposition had a difference of opinion for some years about the work of the Industrial Relations Bureau. The view which we had for a long time, about the role of that Bureau, of course, is shared by both employers and unions. It seems now to be shared, as I understand it, by the Opposition. We thank honourable senators for their constructive comments on the Bill and hope that it has a speedy passage.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated an amendment to clause 22. The purpose of that amendment is to give effect to the proposal that I dealt with in my speech in the second reading debate and which has been referred to by a number of honourable senators in the course of the second reading debate. To explain it once again, briefly, the proposal in this Bill is that to facilitate amalgamations there should be an ability for unions wishing to amalgamate to approach the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and to seek a certificate from that Commission that there is a sufficient community of interest between the unions which would justify amalgamation. If that certificate were given there are provisions in the Bill which would, as I say, facilitate amalgamation in this respect: Amalgamation would require a minimum of only 25 per cent of union members to vote. This Bill provides that only a simple majority of that 25 per cent need vote in favour of the amalgamation. That is a considerable change in the existing law which requires 50 per cent-one half-of the members to vote in support of the amalgamation and, of course, a simple majority of those voting is under existing law sufficient. However, to enable amalgamation to be approved under existing law a 25 per cent vote in favour of it would be required. This provision reduces that number to 12 1/2 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee, which looked at a number of other matters last year, made a recommendation in regard to facilitating amalgamations. It has made a recommendation specifically in relation to this provision of the Bill. The Senate Committee recommended that although in the circumstances I have mentioned it was justified to require only 25 per cent of the members to vote, nevertheless a two-thirds majority-of course there may be more-have to vote in favour of the proposal. That proposal has commended itself to the Opposition. I believe that sufficient explanation of and debate about the amendment has been given. I hope that the Committee will support it. I move:
Page 10, clause 22, proposed new section 158N, paragraph (1) (b), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
'(b) of the members who record formal votes on those ballot papers-
(i) more than two thirds vote in favour of the amalgamation, in a case to which sub-paragraph (1) (a) (i) applies; or
(ii) more than one half vote in favour of the amalgamation, in a case to which sub-paragraph (1) (a) (ii) applies.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak in support of the amendment. It is the minimal safeguard that the Australian community could have. It is a very modest requirement that a certain threshold be met. One of the things that has not been touched on in this debate is the level of technical inadequacy of union ballots. I speak as a former unionist. I am surprised at some of the practices that are still current in the trade union movement. Within the last three years there was a ballot in Queensland for one of the big unions which had 14,000 members. Essentially what happened was the team which won the election stole it. Some 14,000 ballot papers were distributed with a request that they be returned to a General Post Office number at the main post office in Brisbane. The winning team got in and recovered all of the unused ballot papers that had been returned , took them to Bribie Island, filled in the crosses against the candidates whom they were supporting and two of the union organisers then drove back to Brisbane . They had a choice of two roads from Bribie Island to Brisbane: One is down the Bruce Highway and the other is through Redcliffe. They posted the ballot envelopes in different public posting boxes all the way and stole the election in that manner. One of the union organisers claimed that it was just like winning the lottery. Their fall-back position, which has been clearly established, was to duplicate ballot papers. If they had not recovered the returned ballot papers they had a rubber stamp made up with the returning officer's signature on it.

SPEECH.PARA: This matter is terribly important yet we do nothing to control it. I am surprised with the Australian Labor Party. We have taken up so much time in this session talking about referenda, fixed term parliaments and all of the bleeding heart business about giving the Australian public a fair go on parliamentary matters when the Labor Party has an incestuous relationship with the unions. The way they derive so much electoral support and all the rest of it is based on quite corrupt balloting procedures. I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Durack and others on this side of the chamber who seek to impose on this Bill the very minimal level of protection for the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is terribly important that we have a democratically structured union movement in Australia. This is of vital importance. This union movement, at its best, is an essential part of the Australian work force. It is only when the democratic side of the union movement is completely done away with that we have a problem. I do not believe that Senator Button, in his heart, could say that a vote by 12 1/2 per cent of the members could possibly be construed in any way as democratic. I believe that if he were to look at the matter again he would see the logic in securing a vote by 25 per cent of union membership. That is a big enough concession. I remind him that as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation he favoured a vote by two-thirds of union membership. With all the best will in the world, the Opposition would not go along with such a proposal. We do not support the proposal to allow a vote by only 12 1/2 per cent of union membership.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters was not in the chamber when I spoke about this matter. I said in relation to a question from Senator Harradine that this was not necessarily the final solution to all of the problems about amalgamations.
—Yes, I did hear that.

—Yes. I just want to put to Senator Walters that there are very different views about this matter. The first point I make is that in the proposal we put forward in relation to amalgamations every trade unionist has a right to vote. That is secure. I said that there are different views about this matter. What we have put forward in this legislation is precisely what was promised by the Fraser Government in the context of the 1980 election campaign. I am not making an allegation about a broken promise. I am saying that it was the view of the Fraser Government in September 1979 and in the 1980 election campaign that this method was the best. There are differences of view. I know that Senator Walters holds her views very strongly. But we take the view that the whole question of union amalgamations has been held up in this country and that is disastrous for Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis commented on this question without offering his view as to whether it was desirable to have 26 unions in the car industry or the steel industry. We believe very strongly, as I think do many people, that all those questions have been an impediment to the advancement of industry generally. I take on board Senator Walters's point. I say that the Government has not, for the future, a closed mind about it. The National Labour Consultative Council has not examined in the context of this Bill the Senate Select committee's report. I believe it will do so. At the present stage, of course, the legislation that we have brought forward does not apply only to unions. It also applies to registered organisations on both sides and both sides are anxious for this provision to be included. That is the basis of the Government's view. I seek the support of the Committee for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to add to the debate but I must as a result of what Senator Button has just said. I have no objection to there being 26 unions in the car manufacturing game. It is my belief that if those unions represent skilled people, there is a chance that people with skills will be able to be paid for the services that they provide and that would be to their advantage and to the advantage of the Australian car industry. I think that all the talk about demarcation disputes creating a great problem is just eyewash. I acknowledge that occasionally demarcation disputes create major problems. However, this is not the most important thing in regard to the trade union movement.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button talked about giving consideration to points raised by the Opposition. The point is, however, that once this legislation is passed amalgamations will be achieved and then it will be too late for the Government to come back and say: 'Look, we made a mistake'. That is exactly what happened with our Government. We made the mistake of allowing the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union to be created. We have allowed to come into existence a giant organisation which is totally uncontrollable by this Parliament, by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, by the people of Australia or by the rank and file members of that union-totally uncontrollable. As a result of the legislation which the Government will put through today, with the support of the Australian Democrats-that is what I cannot understand; that it is with the support of the Democrats-similar amalgamations will go through and we will be confronted with other massive organisations. Someone said to me: 'Look, Senator, what are you worried about? It is two right wing unions that want to amalgamate'. I do not care whether they are right wing unions, left wing unions or whether they are employer organisations. Giantism is not for the benefit of this nation.

That the words proposed to be omitted (Senator Durack's amendment) be omitted.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AND TELEVISION AMENDMENT (ELECTION BLACKOUT) BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 May, on motion by Senator Button:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge Senator Peter Baume's allowing me to speak first at this time. The Opposition spokesperson in the House of Representatives, Mr Lloyd, said, when speaking to the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Election Blackout) Bill 1983:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be of considerable interest to the House, and certainly to the Opposition, to see what the Australian Democrats do in the Senate . . . If they are to maintain their position and their credibility on this issue, obviously they will have to support our amendment in the Senate.
That refers to the amendment which Senator Peter Baume has now circulated. It removes the pre-election ban on not only comment but also advertising. Mr Lloyd continued:
It will be very interesting to see whether the Australian Democrats maintain their stated position.

I believe it is necessary to give a little of the history of this matter to show why the Australian Democrats intend doing what they propose to do in regard to this Bill. I introduced a private member's Bill on this issue on 26 November 1981. At that time the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party and the then National Country Party of Australia were all opposed to getting rid of the blackout. The Australian Democrats now find themselves in the happy position where all the rest have fallen into step, a position which we hope to achieve on other issues we have taken up. We are also happy that the coalition partners have had a conversion on this, even though it has been a rather 'road to Damascus' type of conversion. It is a pity indeed that the Liberal-National parties did not allow my original proposal to go forward at that time because there would then have been a majority in the Senate and in the House of Representatives to carry it through. We no longer have that majority in the House of Representatives to carry that full-flown position. Therefore it is necessary to see what reform is available to us now. To his credit the Leader of the Opposition in the other place, Mr Peacock, has a long history of opposition to the blackout. I negotiated with him on my original private member's Bill and he intended to move it in the House of Representatives if we got it through the Senate. However, he said to me at that time that it would be necessary to amend my Bill. The amendment he suggested to me was in fact the same as is embodied in the Bill that this Labour Government has now presented. Mr Peacock said that my amended Bill would represent the position that was most acceptable to the Liberals. It is interesting to see that there has been a turnround on even that position.

Although the Australian Democrats would like to support the amendment put forward by the Opposition, we are unable to do so for two main reasons: First, it would mean that we would have no reform in this area. We believe that reform is desirable even if it is only part reform. The Government has been adamant on that point. Secondly, we would be much more amenable to the Opposition's amendment if it were able to support the Australian Democrats proposal for a statutory code of ethics for political advertising, one based on the Trade Practices Act. Since we believe that the voluntary code of restraint on political advertising has certainly not produced any of the worth while goods in this area, we are unable to accede to the Opposition's proposal.

I have circulated an amendment, which I will move at the Committee stage, to pick up a problem that the Government has overlooked. Last year I circulated amendments-which were shown to Senator Button, as then Opposition spokesman for communications-which pointed out an anomaly in my original Bill, the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill 1982. Unfortunately, that anomaly still exists in this Bill. It is the problem of the closing of the polls in the eastern States not corresponding, in time, with the closing of the polls in South Australia, the Northern Territory and Western Australia. The position in Western Australia is the most extreme of all. On most occasions when elections are likely to be held there will be a three-hour difference between the closing of polls in the eastern States and their closing in Western Australia. We would then have the possibility that results from the east could be broadcast on television and radio in Western Australia before the polls had closed in that State. A situation occurs similar to that which occurs in the United States of America and which has been documented as a bandwagon effect whereby something that starts to happen in the eastern States of the United States is picked up and carried through to the west. The people in the west find out the results before they have to vote. I do not think we want that in Australia. Unfortunately, the Government's Bill allows that to occur, as do the Opposition' s proposed amendments. Consequently, I have circulated on behalf of the Australian Democrats an amendment which fits in with the terms of the Bill that the Government brought in and which would enable the Tribunal to prevent the broadcasting of any results until the polls have closed in that State. I believe that that will take us back to the current position. I believe that is the position most people desire to continue, although we do wish to get rid of the absolutely absurd ban on comment. I leave my remarks at that point because the issue has been well canvassed. I have done so twice on introducing my private member's Bill. I welcome the support of the Government and the Opposition in that we at least have a unity of minds in wanting to get rid of some of the absurdities of this ban.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the principle of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment (Election Blackout) Bill 1983. I think I need to explain why we now welcome the principle of the Bill, not having done so previously. The answer is really very simple.
—Malcolm's gone.

—I take Senator Chipp's interjection without comment. This has been a matter of continuing discussion within the Liberal and National parties for some time. How could it not be? Not only has there been a private member's Bill on the subject but it has been a lively and burning issue within the community. It may be self-evident but it is still worth saying that no party is monolithic on issues such as this and no party or parties could be monolithic or have a single view on an issue such as this. It is no secret that within the Liberal and National parties there was no unanimous view, though at the end of the day we had to derive one view towards the Bill. People's views were often opposed. There was lively argument within the parties on this, as there is on other issues. Any view which came out was a balance within the party, the then ministry and the then Cabinet. It may be worth reminding honourable senators that on 27 January 1982 the now Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Peacock, made a statement supporting what we might call the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters compromise on this matter. At that stage he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuation of the blackout is an insult to the intelligence of Australian voters.

That was his view at that time. It was not a view which at that time prevailed in our parties. On 3 September 1982 the then Minister for Communications, my former colleague Mr Neil Brown, referred to the election blackout, as 'a very severe restriction of freedom of expression'. He said that the supporters of the blackout 'will need to establish an overwhelming case to retain it.' Very simply , within our parties there has been lively and continuing debate, a strengthening of support for the view that the blackout has outlived its purpose and its usefulness and a swinging round to the view that it is no longer sustainable.

We have no difficulty with the principle that the blackout should be removed. I note that in 1977 the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its report entitled ' Self-Regulation for Broadcasters' noted that there were only two witnesses at its inquiry who then advocated continuation of the blackout. One was a Mr D. Combe who was the then Queensland branch administrator of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —South Australian.

—I apologise; I should have said South Australian. The other witness-I am sure Senator Button will be pleased to know the juxtaposition-was from the Bowen Family Protection Committee from Queensland. At that stage the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal recommended the deletion of the provision except for the actual day of the elections. So, bodies such as the Tribunal were moving public debate along.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not need to speak for very long. We do support the abolition of the blackout. For that reason, we support the Bill. We do have a remaining concern. Senator Macklin, in indicating that the amendments which we will move at the Committee stage will not be supported by the Australian Democrats, did pick up some of the issues but failed to address one thing that has worried us. If we go back in history, we can illustrate why we are worried. The two examples which everyone quotes and which we may be able to quote again are the Reichstag fire incident and the Zinoviev letter. Both are examples which we can take from history. They are events which actually happened.

I remind the Senate very briefly that in October 1924, four days before the British general elections, the newspapers of that country published a letter purporting to have been written to the British Communist Party by Grigory Zinoviev, the Chairman of Comintern. That letter urged British communists to prepare for the revolution but in the meantime to support the return of the incumbent Labor Government. The scandal caused by its publication was widely believed at the time to have been instrumental in the landslide that occurred against the Labor Party in that election. We have an example of material being introduced close to election day to which, in fact, the victims had very little effective means of response. Whether or not the letter actually produced that effect is still a matter of debate. The letter may well have been a forgery prepared by Russian exiles in Berlin. Nevertheless, the fact that that incident occurred does show an area of possible detriment to people if material which cannot be answered can be introduced close to an election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take your point, but why do you say that the response was limited? Why couldn't those affected respond?

—They had no access to media outlets. The British Labour Party found the working media closed against it on this issue at that time. That is the reason why we propose that the ban on advertising should be removed also. If there were a Zinoviev incident-I will not go through the details of the Reichstag fire-the same kind of principle would apply. A false rumour was spread to influence public opinion at a critical moment. If we can establish, as we have done, that from historical example a capacity does exist for people to be misled close to an election there is a reason for considering whether the advertising ban should go as well. Of course, the same could happen through the print media. We do have a capacity in the print media to get either a response editorially--
—Not on Saturday morning, you don't.

—Not on Saturday morning but, up to Saturday morning, we do have a capacity to take advertising space to try to correct what may be a slander or a misstatement close to the election. It is for that reason that we say that the original Democrat proposal should be supported, that the section should be abolished in totality. I accept, as Senator Macklin said, that there are some remaining problems. He is worried about the quality of some of the advertisements. I do not run away from that. The question is the way in which we approach it. I am very concerned that we have no example in this country which equates in any way with the Zinoviev letter or the Reichstag fire incident. I want no example to occur which could--
—I can give you one that has occurred.
—My colleague, by way of interjection, says that he can give an example. I ask which one.
—I know of one that has occurred in a State election.
—I thank the honourable senator.
—Get on with it and we can get home.

—I indicate to Senator Gareth Evans that I have been speaking for seven minutes. When he can make a speech at the second reading stage of a Bill in seven minutes, there will be hallelujahs going up on all sides. The Bill which was introduced originally by the Australian Democrats is the approach which we favour now. I accept that the Democrats subsequently indicated that they wished to modify their stand.
—There has been a High Court judgment since about electoral advertising.

—I am not attributing motive; I am saying that that is the position which we have reached now. Senator Macklin explained the High Court judgment. There seems to us to be no advantage in trying to continue the blackout. We support the abolition of the blackout. There seems to us to be a potential hazard to political parties, especially small groups, from some kind of ambush close to election day. It is for that reason that we think there should be a capacity for paid advertising to go on even up to the election day if the blackout is removed, and we shall move in Committee appropriate amendments to put that suggestion into effect. Apart from that, the Opposition welcomes the Bill and gives it its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry and Commerce and Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable senators for their contribution to the debate. I must acknowledge Senator Macklin's pioneering endeavours in relation to the abolishment of the broadcasting blackout. Even today he indicated his intention to move a further amendment in respect of which I, as Minister Assisting the Minister for Communications, have given him an undertaking--
—In writing?

—In writing-that we will consider it in connection with the eastern States-western States problem of the time differential on election day. The legislation as it is, is supported by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and, of course, most people who operate in the media. I would argue very briefly that although the Zinoviev case to which Senator Baume has referred-I understand that he was using it by way of example-happened in Britain that country has not had an election blackout in the electronic media for a very long period, and although the Reichstag fire happened in Germany that country has not felt the need to have an election blackout as we have in Australia.
—You are maintaining a blackout on paid advertising, aren't you?

—That is precisely the point I want to come to. I think that if there were to be an incident such as the one involving the Zinoviev letter it would be much more likely to occur in a paid advertisement than in a current affairs program or a news program on the electronic media. It seems to me that one of the great democratic advances that are being made in this legislation is that if an advertisement, whether in the print media or on the electronic media, raises an incident such as that at least there will be an opportunity to reply in a current affairs program or a news program. That is the argument I use against Senator Baume's position on that question.

SPEECH.PARA: I give the Senate one example which happens to have afflicted my party. I am not saying that it has not happened to others. On the eve of, I believe, the 1975 election, a Sydney newspaper published an advertisement about the then Prime Minister-not the caretaker Prime Minister but Mr Whitlam-alleging that he had been involved in extensive land speculation involving millions of dollars in the western suburbs of Sydney. He had no opportunity to repudiate that allegation. He instigated a libel action which cost the newspaper a very substantial sum after the election. It was an immensely damaging allegation to which he had no opportunity to respond. A person in that situation will be able to respond to such an allegation when this legislation is passed. I thank the Senate for its consideration of the Bill and I urge its support in all stages.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment Senator Baume for the way in which he has handled this debate for the Opposition and the reasoned argument he has put for its present stance on it.
