SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Economic Planning Advisory Council Bill 1983. The establishment of this Council is part of Australian Labor Party policy and the proposal was discussed and approved by the National Economic Summit Conference which was held in Canberra in April. The Bill proposes to create an economic advisory body. I emphasise the word ' advisory'. The Council is to be a new statutory authority which will have the function of bringing together the views of various sections of the community. It is quite consistent, I believe, with this new Government's approach to government that it should wish to establish this type of body. It is consistent with its approach to the Summit and its belief that substantially the forces of big government, big unions and big business should be brought together. It may or may not work. However, the Government is certainly entitled to try.

SPEECH.PARA: Believing that the Government has a mandate to introduce this legislation, we will not oppose it. I wish to make it clear, however, that although we do not oppose the legislation, we would not wish to give any guarantee that after the next election, when we are back in government, we will not wish to change it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or that it will succeed.

—Or that it will succeed, as Senator Button said. We are saying that, with a considerable degree of interest and no ill-will, we will support the legislation, with the reservation which I have outlined. I am a little concerned that, because the body has an advisory power only, it does not have the power to conduct an inquiry; it will be at risk of being snowed and not being able to make its own inquiries. I fear that the basic dilemma faced by the body is that if it is at all successful the bureaucracy proper will try to knock it off; if it is not successful, it is a waste of time. I fear that its future will be difficult. Whether it is likely to succeed will probably depend upon the calibre of the people who are appointed to it and their will to make it work.

SPEECH.PARA: I have looked at some other countries that have endeavoured to create similar bodies. I have looked at the Economic Council of Canada, which was established in 1963, the overall responsibilities which it has and the way in which its membership is made up. I feel that the best way to ensure that those who are looking at this matter will have regard to the Canadian model is to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a document which explains the Economic Council of Canada. I do not wish to bore people by referring to it in detail.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ECONOMIC COUNCIL OF CANADA
Chairman: Dr David Slater
Council Secretary: Dr William Haviland
Address: P.O. Box 527, Station B Ottawa, Ontario KIP 5V6 (993-1253)

The Economic Council of Canada was established on 2 August 1963 by an Act of Parliament to advise and recommend the best means by which Canada can achieve the highest possible levels of employment and efficient production in order that the country may enjoy a high and consistent rate of economic growth. In particular, the duties of the Council, as set forth in the Act, are as follows:

(1) to regularly assess, on a systematic and comprehensive basis, the medium- term and long-term prospects of the economy, and to compare such prospects with the potentialities of growth of the economy;
(2) to recommend what government policies, in the opinion of the Council, will best help to realise the potentialities of growth of the economy;
(3) to consider means of strengthening and improving Canada's international financial and trade position;
(4) to study means of increasing Canadian participation in the ownership, control and management of industries in Canada.

(5) to study how economic growth, technological change and automation, and international economic changes may affect employment and income in Canada as a whole, in particular areas of Canada and in particular sectors of the economy;

(6) to study and discuss with representatives of the industries concerned and with representatives of labour, farmers and other primary producers, and other occupational groups and organisations, what specific plans for production and investment in major industries in Canada will best contribute to a high and consistent rate of economic growth;
(7) to study how national economic policies can best foster the balanced economic development of all areas of Canada;

(8) to explore and evaluate particular projects of major significance for the expansion of industrial and other economic activities in Canada, whether or not such projects may involve direct governmental participation, and to make recommendations concerning those projects that, in the opinion of the Council, will contribute to the growth of the Canadian economy;
(9) to encourage maximum consultation and cooperation between labour and management in the fulfilment of the objectives of the Economic Council of Canada Act;
(10) to seek full and regular consultation with appropriate agencies of the governments of the several provinces; and
(11) to conduct, if directed to do so by the Minister, reviews of medium-term or long-term programs of the Government of Canada that are designed to aid or assist industry, labour or agriculture.

On its own initiative, of if directed to do so, the Council is empowered to conduct any study or undertaking related to its duties and to report its findings and/or make recommendations to the government. The Council is required to publish an annual review of the medium- and long-term prospects and problems facing the Canadian economy and is authorised to publish such other reports as it sees fit.

The Council consists of a full-time Chairman and two Dirctors who may serve for a period of seven years, following which time they may be re-appointed for another term. Also serving on the Council on a part-time basis are not more than twenty-five Members representative of a broad range of the Canadian economy across the country.
The Economic Council of Canada reports to Parliament through the Prime Minister .

TALK.START.PARA: —The Norwegian experience is the other one to which I wish to refer because it is of some interest and relevance. It is one which raises the question which may not have been addressed as adequately as it should in relation to the present Government's proposal; that is, the relationship between the function fulfilled by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in Australia-in Norway it is fulfilled by the equivalent of an economic council committee-and this body, the Economic Planning Advisory Council. Centralised wage fixing and economic policy inevitably go together. If we are moving towards centralised wage fixing and the Government does not sort out the relationship between the centralised wage fixing authority and the Economic Planning Advisory Council, it will find that both of them are more limited than they ought to be. Again, I do not wish to delay the Senate by referring in detail to this matter. I draw attention to the fact that it is a matter of some relevance. The body will be a quasi-autonomous national government organisation. I hope it will not be just another qango. It will be able to employ its own staff. It will be able to endeavour to offset the very powerful influence of the Treasury by being able to employ consultants who are independent of the Treasury. Whether that is good or bad has yet to be determined in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: This body will seek to bring together consultation between the various community groups of importance and relevance with regard to economic policy. I find it very strange that the Government, purporting to take some interest in the single most significant area of employment in Australia-the area of small business-has omitted reference to small business in the Bill and in the constitution of the membership of the body. During the National Economic Summit Conference, Mr Gibbons represented the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia. One of the great pleasures that I have had in life was being in on the formation of COSBOA. I drafted the first constitution of that organisation to represent the small business organisations of Australia, a voice which had not been heard adequately. It needs to be heard adequately. Bearing that in mind , I shall be moving with enthusiasm the amendment which has been circulated in the name of the Opposition, for the specific representation of small business on EPAC. When speaking at the Summit, Mr Gibbons said:

Our Council, through its member associations, directly or indirectly works and acts for some 150,000 individual small businesses, primarily at present in the tertiary sector where the great bulk of small businesses operate. But we are no less concerned for the wellbeing of every one of the estimated 400,000 small businesses throughout Australia which provide for the employment and self- employment of millions of Australians.

He went on to refer to other aspects of the importance of the role of small business. I save time by simply drawing honourable senators' attention to his speech, which is recorded from page 15 of the record of proceedings of the Summit, which is Volume 2 of the Summit documents and proceedings. I commend to those concerned with this piece of legislation the matters put by Mr Gibbons. Shortly, in the Committee stage, I shall be moving an amendment which would enable small business to be assured of representation.

I also wish in Committee to get some response from the Government on another matter which has concerned some people-that is, that three States will be represented on EPAC on a rotational basis, with each State being involved for two years at a time. 'State' includes the Northern Territory, so in effect there will be seven States under the definition in the Bill. The three persons on the Council who will represent the States will be nominated by the governments of those States, but there is no provision in the Bill as to how the first three representatives will be determined. There is also no provision as to whether those who have been selected by the government of the day of a State can have their appointment terminated in the event of a change of government within a State. Also, I can find no provision which says what will happen in the event of a change of government at the Federal level.

It is to be hoped that this Council will work well and successfully, as regards the positions. Appointments are to include the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and , as I understand it, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations or a similar Federal Minister. If there is a change of government, presumably there will be a change of at least those three people on the Council. But what will happen to the other appointments in the event of a change of Federal government? This does not seem to have been made clear yet. It is important. I am not suggesting that it is a matter of criticism, but an explanation is required. Perhaps the Minister, in responding, will give us some indication on those questions. First, what will happen with regard to the States? How will they draw up a roster of representation? Secondly, what happens in the event of a change of State government? Thirdly, what happens in the event of a change of Federal government?

I refer briefly to one or two aspects of the speech of my colleague in the other place, Mr Shipton, which is reported at pages 891 and 892 of Hansard for 24 May 1983. He set out a number of matters. I do not intend to repeat them at this stage of the proceedings. I am sure that remark will be received with some gratitude but I do not wish it to be taken as meaning that I do not support the points made by my colleague in referring to a number of aspects of small business, the mini-Budget and his concern to ensure that the interests of small business are well protected in any steps taken by this Parliament. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to make those all too brief points about a Bill which I think is of extreme importance. It may be of very great assistance to Australia or it may be a failure. The Opposition will support it with a view to seeing how it succeeds or otherwise. We wish it well.

It is of considerable concern to me that the only reference to women in this piece of legislation is in clause 9 (7) which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Appointments of members shall, as far as practicable, be such that the Council contains both men and women.

That is practically meaningless, of course, since 'as far as practicable' can be just left there and in effect nothing will be done. It had been my intention to amend clause 9 (1) (h) so that after the word 'members' in that paragraph would be inserted the words 'at least one of whom shall be a woman, and at least one of whom shall be a man', and to similarly amend sub-clause 9 (7) by leaving out the sub-clause entirely and inserting the following new sub-clause:
Appointments of members shall be such that at least three of the members are women and at least three of the members are men.

It is all too easy at the moment without this sort of thing written into legislation or without the Minister concerned offering some sort of commitment for the sort of thing to occur as appears to have occurred with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board. At the moment I can only refer to an article in a paper this morning which indicated that only one of nine members on the short list is female. That may or may not be the case, but what has happened as a result of that report is that women have been ringing me today and saying: 'So much for the commitment to affirmative action.' If it is not true, if this is just flag flying or kite flying on the part of the paper concerned, all to the good. If it is correct, that is all the more reason for the sort of amendment that I had intended to move being written into the legislation.

A whole host of women of whom I can think would be suitable not only to go on EPAC but also to go on the proposed Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board. There are women like Mary Beasley from South Australia who is presently the Commissioner of the Public Service Board and ex-Commissioner for Equal Opportunity, Susan Armstrong, presently Assistant Deputy Ombudsman in New South Wales and previously director of the Legal Services Commission in South Australia, and Elizabeth Proust, a lawyer and a very capable woman who is well aware of business interests and able to represent them capably on a Council such as this. Indeed, I suggest that any 'Businesswoman of the Year' and most of the runners-up in that award would be at least as competent as most of the men who would be appointed to this Board to deal with the sorts of pressures relating to the economic planning of Australia in the future.

It is not my intention, however, having made that impassioned plea, to move those amendments. I say that for the same reasons why we are not supporting Senator Peter Rae's amendment. The point has had to be made in both instances. Having made it, I think it is time to retire gracefully in the hope that the Government will see that affirmative action, both in the area of women's representation and in the area of small business, is a necessity if we want genuine consensus on this Council and accept that the spirit, if not the fact, of the amendment is in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my remarks to clause 9 which relates to the membership of the Economic Planning Advisory Council. In so doing , I make a preliminary observation so I do not have to get up during the debate on the third reading. SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to what has been said by Senator Haines about the absence of representation for women on this council. Admittedly clause 7 (7) states:
Appointments of members shall, as far as practicable, be such that the Council contains both men and women.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Jack Evans mentioned the importance of stimulating small business activity. Senator Jack Evans-You will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly thank those honourable senators who have made a contribution on this matter. Senator Haines failed to move an amendment about which she spoke. As I indicated earlier, the view of the Government is that an economic planning advisory council should seek to have the best available advice. In a sense what I am saying cuts across what has been said about small business, what has been said about women and what might be said about men. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine raised a very serious point. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -Now that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has been enabled to leave the chamber, and leave Canberra apparently, we now come to a most important piece of legislation. The Community Employment Bill 1983 seeks to appropriate $300m for employment schemes. The Bill certainly is in line with the policies of this Government. It is pleasing that the Government has carried out some of its promises. Very few promises have been implemented. I congratulate the Government on the fact that, on this occasion, it is carrying out something it said it would do, which is a very rare event in the life of this Government. It is a very important financial measure. A very large amount of money has been set aside for the next financial year to take effect from 1 July. It therefore is very urgent legislation. I find it rather strange that the Government has decided to put it at the bottom of its list of priorities today, even to the extent of dropping it behind the Economic Planning Advisory Council Bill that we have just dealt with for the convenience of the Attorney-General.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation deserves a great deal of consideration. It is a Bill that should have been brought on by the Government at a time when consideration could have been properly given to it and adequately debated in this chamber. As a result of the mismanagement of the business of this House, particularly today, this legislation is now brought on at the very end of the dying few minutes, virtually, of this session when most of the Government senators have left the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have accommodated you people.

—Ha, ha! Because of the way in which the legislative program has been handled large numbers of senators on the Opposition side have also been obliged to leave the chamber. The responsibility for this ragged end of the session is on the head of the Government because of its mismanagement of the business of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports the Bill. It contains provision for a job creation program in the true sense of the word. It is a program that has had progenitors from time to time in periods of unemployment. The Opposition does not believe this is the best way of tackling unemployment. Nevertheless, it provides an amelioration of the problem for a number of people for a limited time. It should be made clear that this job creation scheme which will provide 70,000 jobs for up to six months is a palliative only. I hope that it will be understood as such and that people will not believe that by measures of this kind the unemployment problem can be solved or that it can be solved in any long term sense. If there are any rises in wages the significance of this proposed scheme will be greatly reduced. The effectiveness of this scheme will be maximised if there is proper economic management and a stimulus for economic recovery in this country. The Opposition wants to emphasise its concern about this Bill being an effective solution to our economic problems. Therefore I move:
At end of motion, add 'but the Senate-

(a) is of the opinion that the Government should acknowledge that permanent jobs will only be created when economic recovery occurs and should do its utmost to implement policies consistent with the following extract from the National Economic Summit communique:
(i) there is a recognition that to achieve recovery will require restraint in expectations and claims from all sections of the community except the impoverished (paragraph 2),
(ii) it is a legitimate expectation that income of the employed shall be increased in real terms through time in line with productivity (paragraph 8), and

(iii) the preservation of the private sector as a profitable operating sector is essential to Australia's well-being and to encourage job creating investment both from within Australia and abroad (paragraph 9); and

(b) resolves that the Government should seek to extend the wages pause and subsequent wage restraint until economic recovery, increased investment and consequent job creation have commenced strongly'.
I emphasise in particular the last part of that amendment, namely the absolute necessity for the Government to:
. . . seek to extend the wages pause and subsequent wage restraint until economic recovery . . . have commenced strongly.

As I said earlier, any scheme of this kind, any attempt to create a large number of jobs, albeit of a temporary character, will not be effective unless there is a continuation of restraint on wages and restraint generally in the community. The policy that the Fraser Government initiated at the end of last year should continue, at least until the end of this year. I am afraid that, although the Government has committed itself to these principles in the Economic Summit communique, there is every sign that it will buckle under union pressures and the wages pause will not remain in place very much longer.

If that is the case-I am afraid it is-this sort of scheme, like any similar scheme or indeed almost anything else the Government may dream up, is doomed to failure. The only way in which we will get any long term solution to the problems of unemployment, to Australia's economic recovery, is through the growth of the private sector and the creation of real jobs; not just jobs of a temporary kind, which are all that this measure will be able to provide.

As I said, the Opposition supports this measure. We hope that it will not prove to be just a palliative. We hope also that it will not be an illusion and that large numbers of people who are presently unemployed will derive some benefit from it. We firmly believe-we hope that the Government will accept this as well- that it is no long term solution to the problem of unemployment. Very different and much more positive economic policies are required from this Government if that object is to be achieved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Community Employment Bill 1983 is a very important Bill. As Senator Durack has said, it is one of a series of important Bills which has literally streaked through this place today. I take this opportunity of supporting the comments made by Senator Peter Rae; it is improper for this place to deal with legislation of this importance at the speed at which we are being required to do so today. I suppose that the Government has been having its honeymoon. Okay, but I give notice that, speaking for myself, I will not be so tolerant of this sort of situation in the future. I hope that in future the Government will try to introduce legislation in a reasonable way, dispersed throughout a session. It is perfectly possible for the Government to do that. I see that, on the other side of the House, Senator Button is smiling. I remember how often he raised this point when he was Leader of the Opposition. I remind him of that now. I remind him of the numerous Hansard references where he will find a record of his doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: To return to the Bill, in the view of the Australian Democrats this is an important Bill, not only because of what is in it but also because of what is not in it. Senator Durack's points, I think, were good. We see in the Bill useful areas of work, I suppose, because at least they provide employment for desperate people who want it, but they are unimaginative, palliative measures which to me have a rather unpleasant tang of the relief work connotations of the 1930s. People will build and maintain local roads. They will engage in project activity involving water supply improvement programs in country towns, whatever that might mean. That is referred to in the second reading speech of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button). To the extent that they can provide useful training for people and a career, employment programs will be of value. But I question those particular projects. They will, I suppose, train people to construct and maintain local roads and to engage in project activity involving water supply improvements. This may not be what many young Australians want to do.

Further on in the Minister's second reading speech is an indication of what I think is a remarkable cop-out on the part of the Government. It has said that the community will have an input on projects which will conform to certain guidelines. I would have thought that the Government would have preferred to come forward with something that had some imagination and some future for this country. I draw attention to comments that have been made by leading citizens in Australia. I refer to a comment by Sir Mark Oliphant that we need to think big, that it is time the Government got itself together and told the young people of this country that they could serve it best by getting into something large, something which is of value to the community and which has a permanent wealth- producing future and a job-producing potential as well. One such project which was suggested by Sir Mark Oliphant, which was particularly relevant in light of the difficulties over negotiating the sale of North West Shelf gas, was a gas pipeline across the country which would bring that enormous source of energy to the eastern States.

I was recently in New Zealand. I went there to see the project which has been carried out at Taranaki to convert natural gas to methanol and petrol. New Zealand-a much smaller country that ours-can carry out that sort of major project. I discussed it with both the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition of that country. The project is being carried out by consensus. It is time that the Government got itself together and, now that its honeymoon is over , brought to this country something of real significance to employment in this country, which will produce jobs and wealth for this country into the future.

Speaking briefly to the Opposition's amendment, as I indicated earlier, I think to the Opposition, the Australian Democrats do not support it. We support the first part of the amendment, paragraph (a), because it expresses good sentiments reflecting those of the National Economic Summit Conference. But we do not support paragraph (b) of the amendment, which states:
(b) resolves that the Government should seek to extend the wages pause and subsequent wage restraint until economic recovery, increased investment and consequent job creation have commenced strongly.

We believe that the job of persuading the community to accept restraint cannot be carried out in such a cavalier fashion and that the community will not wait until all of these things have com- menced strongly and everybody in business is making a fortune before wages can be increased. I suggest to the Opposition that this is a curiously naive and unrealistic amendment and I suggest it deserves our rejection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take only a minute of the Senate's time. I am concerned at the tragic lack of understanding by the Government of how the commercial world operates, and in particular the lack of appreciation of the importance of profitability in companies and how one must control wages and get productivity out of people. The section of the Community Employment Bill which deals simply with a 'make work' program is terribly shortsighted. Certainly it is important to give people employment as a stop gap measure. But surely there are some people who can advise the Labor Government how to make long term jobs available for people instead of publicly taking the line that we are committed to millions of unemployed people in this country. Senator Button, in debating a matter of public importance earlier this session, just accepted that we will have an extraordinarily high level of unemployment. I do not accept that at all. In the midst of economic depressions we always find that there is no hope around but we will recover from this one if we have the right positive policies from the Government. Instead of running with short term 'make work' programs one of the things the Government should do is look to the creation of national assets, things that this generation and future generations will use.

SPEECH.PARA: The point raised by Senator Mason on the conversion of natural gas to liquid petroleum in New Zealand refers to the sort of program that we could be looking at. It makes it all the more galling that the Government took $20m out of the Brisbane Airport program because that is a national asset, something that is needed today. It is something that will be of benefit to future generations. I implore this Government to lift its eyes above its navel, look a bit further down the track and try to get for people jobs which will benefit the country.

As Senator Button is in the chamber for once I mention that he attacked me the other day for being a defender of small business. On one of the few occasions during this session on which I have had the opportunity of asking a question concerning small business, Senator Button replied by getting into me for defending small business. He might like to know what people in the market place are saying. The question now is: How do you buy a small business when there is an Australian Labor Party Government in power? The answer is: You buy a big one and wait six months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator MacGibbon cannot point to any Hansard which shows me criticising him for supporting small business. What he has just said is not correct. If he is so concerned about spending money on pipelines, on the Brisbane Airport and things of that kind, he might have thought before he voted yesterday on the tax recoupment legislation, because there was $500m there which could have been spent on those projects and on putting people back to work. If Senator MacGibbon is concerned about infrastructure programs in Australia and about creating employment by these means he should contemplate the one industry which flourished in Australia in the seven years of his Government-tax avoidance. That industry flourished and the Opposition is still promoting it. It does not employ many people. I find some of his views quite extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not say in the Senate that employment would continue to decline. What I said, and I repeat it-everybody who knows anything about this would agree with me-is that employment in traditional manufacturing industry in Australia will decline. That is the challenge which governments have to face. By way of advice, I would not be too concerned about that particular issue.

Of course everybody has pet projects that he wants people to work on and governments to spend money on. Senator Mason mentioned a few. I find it extraordinary that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place devoted a third of his speech to the employment situation in the Senate-pointing to the number of honourable senators who had gone home, and such things as the management of business in the Senate. One-third of his speech contained little lectures about the extent of unemployment. He is an expert on that; he ought to know. In the short time it has been in office this Government has created programs designed to tackle the worst unemployment situation that this country has ever faced since the Great Depression. Those conditions were created in the last seven years. I am interested in Senator Durack's conversion, on the road to Damascus, in regard to unemployment. He suddenly recognises that there is some value in job creation schemes of this kind-something which was opposed by the Fraser Government year after year. The Government has no illusions at all-in introducing this program-that it is not tackling the question of long term unemployment in this country. It is saying that there is a situation of social tragedy in this country, one that particularly affects young people and the long term unemployed, one that has to be tackled as a matter of priority. It is saying that it is important, even by their working under such a scheme as this, to give people a stake in the country in terms of employment. We do not believe for a moment that schemes of this kind will create long term permanent employment, a solution to the sudden and tragic crisis with which this country is confronted.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are spending a lot of money and missing opportunities, acting in a simplistic knee-jerk way.

—I know it costs a lot of money. I will tell Senator MacGibbon something: Every one per cent increase in unemployment in Australia costs this Government $1 billion. Under the Fraser Government unemployment increased by 4 1 /2 per cent every year. That added to the annual deficit $4.5 billion that could not be spent on creating new jobs, creating changes in Australian industry and creating the infrastructure that the Opposition is talking about. That is the sort of burden with which we are confronted. In that context it is just trivial to talk about this sum of money being spent on an important solution to a tragic social problem which is possessing this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make one other comment about Senator Durack's speech. It just shows that, after years in the Parliament and five or six years as a Minister in the last Government, he has learnt nothing. He moved an amendment on behalf of the Opposition. There were some very good points in the amendment. I agreed with all the points mentioned in paragraph (a). The Government has to take account of those things. But the sad thing is that, when Senator Durack talks about extending the wages pause, he should think for a moment about the practicality of that. His Government was never able to agree with the State governments about how long the wages pause would last. Who would he extend the wages pause for? Would he extend it for people under Federal awards or for Commonwealth employees , or would he extend it for the substantial mass of employees under State government awards and determinations? There was never agreement on that question .

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment says you should seek to.

—We should seek to extend the wages pause? There is nothing wrong with seeking to extend it but we have a different view about the substantial issue. Senator Durack says that we as a Government will buckle to union pressure and that, as he has been saying for years, the result of buckling to union pressure will be a wage explosion. The biggest wage explosion that this country has seen for ages occurred in 1981 and 1982 under his Government. Did it buckle to union pressure? Was that why the wage explosion occurred or did it occur because of the sheer stupidity of that Government in failing to have a wages policy? I think probably the second thing happened. If Senator Durack, in the Budget session and next year, goes on with this puerile level of debate, suggesting that the problems of employment, manufacturing industry and so on are related simply to one issue, we will not get very far as a national parliament. I thank the Senate for its consideration of and warm support for this Bill. I hope that it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 3 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are travel agents in far north Queensland required to contact the Qantas office in Townsville or Brisbane for assistance in difficult fare construction, up-dating of fare knowledge and provision of Qantas material for day to day operation of their travel office because these services are not available from Qantas' general sales agent in north Queensland.
(2) Are Qantas reservations made in North Queensland effected through Brisbane via an inwatts service or through Qantas' general sales agent.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Qantas has advised that travel agents in far north Queensland should not be required to contact Qantas in Townsville or Brisbane for assistance with difficult fare quotes, as Air Queensland in Cairns, Qantas' general sales agent in north Queensland, would have the expertise to answer all queries. Qantas provides regular training in Cairns for agents and Air Queensland to enable updating of their general knowledge of current fares. Further, Air Queensland, as the Qantas general sales agent in the region, provides a distribution service for Qantas tariff notices and any Qantas material used for day to day operations by north Queensland travel agents.

(2) Qantas has advised that, since 26 April 1982, Qantas reservations from north Queensland have been channelled through Brisbane to the company's central reservations unit in Sydney, at Qantas expense, via the inwatts facility. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1983 (Hansard, page 869-70) Senator Jack Evans asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism the following question without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism aware that at present there are some four separate competing offices in London, each promoting individual Australian States and Territories as tourist destinations? Is the Minister aware of the expressed wish of the Australian tourist industry that the Commonwealth Government co-ordinate marketing of Australian tourism overseas out of one office per country, with the individual States and Territories each having representation in each office as they desire? What steps has the Government taken to persuade the States, and Territories to forgo their individual tourist promotions overseas and join the Commonwealth in one major advertising push to sell Australia as a holiday destination rather than a collection of competing States, as was undertaken by the Minister in his address to the National Economic Summit Conference? Will the Minister be raising this issue at the annual meeting of Federal and State tourism Ministers tomorrow ?
I have been supplied with the following information:
The Minister is aware of various State governments actively promoting their States as tourist destinations overseas.

The Minister is also aware that a task force of the Australian Travel Industry Association reporting in September 1982 on Tourism in the 80s found strong support of the established role of the Australian Tourist Commission in promoting Australia overseas and for its research and other industry supporting initiatives.

The Australian Tourist Commission, as the Government's tourism promotional arm, has developed initiatives for consultation and co-ordination with the States and Qantas. Liaison Committees have been established in Australia and each of Australia's main tourist markets. This had led to close harmonisation of overseas activities and general adoption of the Commission's marketing platforms by States and industry.
For example, recently in London, the States industry and the Commission co- operated in producing 'Corroboree', a presentation on Australia to the British Travel Trade.

In addition, the Commonwealth Government is actively encouraging the Commission in seconding State/ Territory officers to its overseas offices. At present there are seconded officers in Auckland and Singapore. Secondments to the Tokyo Office are currently under consideration.

The Commonwealth Government is also encouraging the Commission to investigate the possible establishment of 'Australia Centres' in various overseas markets. The aim of these Centres will be to provide a cohesive and comprehensive source of product information which will facilitate the marketing of Australia.
These matters were discussed at the recent Tourist Ministers' Council meeting in Sydney. There will be continuing discussions on the cohesive promotion of Australia overseas.
It is the policy of this Government that it should assume the sole responsibility of promoting Australia overseas, after consultation with the States.
